<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>2003 Outlook</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Despite the progress made in 2002, as a result of the continued economic
environment for the airline industry, we expect to incur a significant loss in
the first quarter and for the full year 2003. We believe near-term revenues
will continue to be negatively impacted by the soft economic conditions and the
decline in business traffic. In addition, fuel prices have remained and may
continue to remain well above historical norms due to the threat of and the
commencement of military action against Iraq and continued political
tension in Venezuela. Although there can be no assurances, we believe
that cash flow from operating activities coupled with existing cash balances
and financing commitments will be adequate to fund our operating and capital
needs as well as enable us to maintain compliance with our various debt
agreements through at least December&nbsp;31, 2003. See &#147;<I>Business &#150; Risk Factors
Relating to America West and Industry Related Risks</I>,&#148; above and &#147;<I>Liquidity and
Capital Resources,</I>&#148; below.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Results of Operations</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Summary of Holdings&#146; Financial Results</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holdings recorded a consolidated loss before the cumulative effect of a
change in accounting principle of $179.7&nbsp;million in 2002, a diluted loss per
share of $5.33. This compares to a consolidated net loss of $249.9&nbsp;million or
$7.42 per diluted share, in 2001. Including the cumulative effect of a change
in accounting principle related to the Company&#146;s adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142,
<I>&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets,&#148; </I>on January&nbsp;1, 2002, Holdings&#146; net loss
for 2002 was $387.9&nbsp;million, or $11.50 per diluted share. See Note 3,
<I>&#147;Adoption of New Accounting Standard&#148; </I>in Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements. The 2002 results include special charges of $19.0&nbsp;million
 primarily related to the restructuring completed on
January&nbsp;18, 2002, (see Note 14, <I>&#147;Special Charges&#148; </I>in Notes to Consolidated
Financial Statement) and a gain of $4.9&nbsp;million related to a change in the Company&#146;s vacation policy for certain administrative
employees. The Company also recognized a nonoperating charge of $2.8
million related to the write-off of the Company&#146;s
investment in an e-commerce entity and a nonoperating gain of $8.5
million related to the federal government assistance
received under the Air Transportation Safety and system Stabilization Act. See
Note 15, <I>&#147;Nonoperating Income (Expense) &#151; Other, Net&#148; </I>in Notes to Consolidated
Financial Statements. The 2001 results include a nonoperating gain of
$108.2&nbsp;million related to the federal government
assistance, an $11.0&nbsp;million gain resulting
from the settlement in March 2001 of a lawsuit related to an air-to-ground
telecommunication system that was previously written off and an $8.8&nbsp;million
gain from an insurance settlement in the fourth
quarter of 2001. These gains were offset by $141.6&nbsp;million of special
charges resulting from the impairment of ERV and
owned aircraft and engines, as well as the early termination of aircraft leases
and severance expenses following the reduction-in-force in 2001. The Company
also recognized a $2.1&nbsp;million loss related to
the write down to realizable value of the Company&#146;s investment in Book4golf.com
in the third quarter of 2001. The Company recorded a consolidated income tax
benefit for financial reporting purposes of $35.1&nbsp;million for the 2002 period
on a loss before income tax benefit and cumulative effect of a change in
accounting principle of $214.8&nbsp;million. The benefit is primarily
due to additional carryback losses made available in 2002 as a result
of the enactment of new tax legislation allowing an extended
carryback period under the Job Creation and Workers Assistance Act of
2002. This compares to an income tax benefit
of $74.5&nbsp;million in the 2001 period on a pretax loss of $324.4&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2000, the Company recognized net income of $7.7&nbsp;million and income tax
expense of $17.1&nbsp;million. Diluted earnings per share for 2000 were $0.22.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">24</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">5.2</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">(11.9</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap><FONT size="2">)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P>
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(a)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Average daily aircraft utilization &#150; The average number of block
hours per day for all aircraft in service.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(b)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Available seat mile (&#147;ASM&#148;) &#150; A basic measure of production. It is
one seat flown one statute mile.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">25</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>




<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(c)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Block hours &#150; The hours measured from the moment an aircraft first
moves under its own power, including taxi time, for the purposes of
flight until the aircraft is docked at the next point of landing and its
power is shut down.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(d)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Average stage length &#150; The average of the distances flown on each
segment of every route.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(e)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Average passenger journey &#150; The average one-way trip measured in
statute miles for one passenger origination.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(f)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Revenue passenger mile (&#147;RPM&#148;) &#150; A basic measure of sales volume. It
is one passenger flown one mile.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(g)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Load factor &#150; The percentage of available seats that are filled with
revenue passengers.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(h)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Passenger enplanements &#150; The number of passengers on board an
aircraft including local, connecting and through passengers.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(i)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Yield &#150; A measure of airline revenue derived by dividing passenger
revenue by revenue passenger miles and expressed in cents per mile.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(j)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Passenger revenue per available seat mile (&#147;RASM&#148;) &#150; Total passenger
revenues divided by total available seat miles.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(k)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Total revenue per available seat mile &#150; Total operating revenues
divided by total available seat miles.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>2002 Compared with 2001</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA recorded an operating loss of $164.2&nbsp;million in 2002 compared to an
operating loss of $423.4&nbsp;million in 2001. Loss before income tax benefit and
the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle was $219.6&nbsp;million in
2002 compared to a pretax loss of $326.2&nbsp;million in 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total operating revenues for 2002 were $2.0&nbsp;billion. Passenger revenues
were $1.9&nbsp;billion in 2002, which was relatively flat when compared to 2001. A
4.2% increase in RPMs exceeded a 1.8% increase in capacity, as measured by
ASMs, resulting in a 1.7 point increase in load factor to 73.6%. The increase
in load factor was offset by a 4.6% decrease in yield driven by a significant
decline in business travel and the introduction of security fees paid by
passengers. As a result, RASM decreased 2.5% to 7.14 cents in 2002 from 7.32
cents in 2001. Cargo revenues for 2002 decreased $6.3&nbsp;million (18.5%) due to
lower freight and
mail volumes following the September&nbsp;11, 2001 terrorist attacks. Other
revenues, which consist primarily of alcoholic beverage sales, contract service
sales, service charges and Mesa Airlines&#146; net revenues, increased $9.0&nbsp;million
(19.9%) due primarily to higher ticket refund and reissue penalty fees for
ticketing changes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Excluding special charges of $19.0&nbsp;million and $141.6&nbsp;million recognized
in 2002 and 2001, respectively, (see Note 14, <I>&#147;Special Charges&#148; </I>in Notes to
Financial Statements) operating expenses decreased $146.3&nbsp;million or 6.3%,
while ASMs increased 1.8% in 2002 as compared to 2001. As a result, CASM
excluding special charges decreased 8.1% to 7.98 cents in 2002 from 8.68 cents
in 2001. Significant changes in the components of operating expense per ASM
are explained as follows:
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">26</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Salaries and related costs per ASM decreased 2.9% due primarily to
lower average full-time equivalent headcount in 2002 as compared to 2001
despite a 1.8% increase in ASMs. A 3.9% decrease in the average number
of full-time equivalent employees (&#147;FTE&#148;) was offset in part by a 2.9%
increase in average salaries and related costs per FTE as a result of
higher medical, disability and workers&#146; compensation insurance costs
($16.9&nbsp;million).</FONT></TD>

reduction of rental rates negotiated with AWA&#146;s aircraft lessors as part
of the financial restructuring that was completed in January 2002.</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Other rents and landing fees expense per ASM increased 10.8% due
primarily to higher airport rents ($7.9&nbsp;million), landing fees ($5.2
million) and costs for borrowed parts ($3.6&nbsp;million). A $2.5&nbsp;million
increase in flight simulator rents, primarily as a result of the sale
and leaseback of three previously owned flight simulators in the third
quarter of 2001, also contributed to the increase. These increases were
offset in part by a decrease in aircraft engine rents ($1.5&nbsp;million).</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Aircraft fuel expense per ASM decreased 14.1% due primarily to an
11.9% decrease in the average price per gallon of fuel to 73.1 cents in
2002 from 83.0 cents in 2001.</FONT></TD>

the United States, effective March&nbsp;21, 2002.</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Aircraft maintenance materials and repair expense per ASM decreased
3.7% due primarily to lower aircraft C-Check ($12.7&nbsp;million), engine
overhaul ($4.1&nbsp;million), airframe maintenance ($3.0&nbsp;million) and
engineering order ($1.3&nbsp;million) expenses. These decreases were offset
in part by a $12.8&nbsp;million increase in the accrual for the estimated
costs of maintenance required to be performed upon the return of leased
aircraft and a $3.4&nbsp;million increase in capitalized maintenance
amortization expense.</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Depreciation and amortization expense per ASM increased 14.9% due
primarily to higher amortization expense related to computer hardware,
software and facility improvements ($8.5&nbsp;million) and aircraft leasehold
improvements ($2.3&nbsp;million). An increase in depreciation expense
related to rotable aircraft parts ($1.7&nbsp;million) also contributed to the
increase. These increases were offset in part by a decrease in airframe
depreciation expense ($2.3&nbsp;million).</FONT></TD>

Assets,&#148; </I>the Company wrote off its balance of reorganization value in
excess of amounts allocable to identifiable assets, effective January&nbsp;1,
2002, resulting in a $19.9&nbsp;million decrease in amortization expense in
2002 when compared to 2001. The impairment loss of $187.9&nbsp;million was
recorded as the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.
See Note 3, <I>&#147;Adoption of New Accounting Standard&#148; </I>in Notes to Financial

    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Other operating expenses per ASM decreased 2.3% to 1.64 cents from
1.68 cents primarily due to decreases in interrupted trip and baggage
claim expenses ($12.0&nbsp;million), professional, technical
and legal fees ($10.7&nbsp;million), catering ($13.3&nbsp;million), advertising
($5.4&nbsp;million), overnight and on-call maintenance expenses ($3.6
million), computer reservations system book fees ($3.0&nbsp;million) and
furnished accommodations ($2.4&nbsp;million). These decreases were offset in
part by higher traffic liability insurance expense ($31.2&nbsp;million), the
settlement in 2001 of a lawsuit related to an air-to-ground
telecommunication system that was previously written off ($11.0&nbsp;million)
and an insurance claim ($8.8&nbsp;million).</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Excluding the federal government assistance of $8.5&nbsp;million and $108.2
million recognized in 2002 and 2001, respectively, net nonoperating expenses
increased $52.8&nbsp;million to $63.9&nbsp;million in 2002 from $11.1&nbsp;million in 2001.
Net interest expense increased $45.7&nbsp;million in 2002 due to higher average
outstanding debt as a result of the government guaranteed loan, while interest
income decreased $5.4&nbsp;million. Higher average cash balances were offset by
lower escrow balances from the 2001-1 Pass Through Trust Certificates and lower
interest rates in 2002 compared to 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">27</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>2001 Compared with 2000</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA recorded an operating loss of $423.4&nbsp;million in 2001 compared to an
operating loss of $12.7&nbsp;million in 2000. Loss before income taxes for 2001 was
$326.2&nbsp;million compared to $15.1&nbsp;million of pretax income in 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total operating revenues for 2001 were $2.0&nbsp;billion. Passenger revenues
were $1.9&nbsp;billion in 2001, a decrease of $237.9&nbsp;million or 10.9% from 2000.
RASM in 2001 decreased 9.0% to 7.32 cents from 8.04 cents due to a reduction in
demand for air travel following the September&nbsp;11 terrorist attacks and a
reduction in business travel driven by a slowing economy. Yield decreased
10.7% to 10.18 cents in 2001 from 11.40 cents in 2000. ASMs decreased 2.1% in
2001 as compared to 2000 while RPMs were relatively flat year-over-year,
resulting in a 1.4 point increase in load factor. Cargo revenues for 2001
decreased $3.6&nbsp;million (9.5%) due to lower freight and mail volumes following
the September&nbsp;11 terrorist attacks. Other revenues, which consist primarily of
alcoholic beverage sales, contract service sales, service charges and Mesa
Airlines net revenues, decreased $28.4&nbsp;million (38.6%) due primarily to lower
net revenues from AWA&#146;s code sharing agreement with Mesa Airlines, principally
as a result of the decline in demand for air travel and the slowing economy.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating expenses excluding $141.6&nbsp;million of special charges recognized
in 2001 (see Note 14, <I>&#147;Special Charges&#148; </I>in Notes to Financial Statements) were
relatively flat year-over-year, while ASMs decreased 2.1% in 2001 as compared
to 2000. As a result, CASM excluding special charges increased 2.1% to 8.68
cents in 2001 from 8.50 cents in 2000. A significant contributor to the
increase in CASM was the post-September&nbsp;11 suspension of air service and
subsequent reduction of AWA&#146;s flight schedule as a result of reduced demand for
air travel, which reduced ASMs without a commensurate reduction in expenses.
Significant changes in the components of operating expense per ASM are
explained as follows:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Salaries and related costs per ASM increased 10.4% primarily due to
an increase in salaries and related costs per employee, the reduction in
ASMs and a higher number of employees in 2001 to support anticipated
growth. Average salaries and related costs per FTE increased 6.5%
primarily due to higher disability and medical insurance premiums ($13.5
million), a new collective bargaining agreement with the Company&#146;s fleet
service workers, which was entered into in June 2000 that included
higher wage rates, and contractual wage increases required by the
Company&#146;s agreement with its pilots. Payroll expense for fleet service
personnel increased by $10.5&nbsp;million and pilot salaries increased by
$5.8&nbsp;million in 2001. The average number of full-time equivalent
employees increased 1.4% year-over-year while ASMs decreased 2.1%.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Aircraft rent expense per ASM increased 9.7% due primarily to the net
addition of five leased aircraft to the fleet during 2001 as compared to
2000.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Other rents and landing fees expense per ASM increased 9.7% due
primarily to higher airport rentals ($8.0&nbsp;million) and landing fees
($3.8&nbsp;million), which were offset in part by lower costs for borrowed
parts ($2.6&nbsp;million.)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Aircraft fuel expense per ASM decreased 6.1% due primarily to a 5.8%
decrease in the average price per gallon of fuel to 83.0 cents in 2001
from 88.1 cents in 2000.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Agency commissions expense per ASM decreased 11.3% due primarily to a
10.9% decrease in passenger revenues. An increase in the percentage of
non-commissionable revenue in 2001 primarily as a result of increased
usage of the Company&#146;s website and other lower cost distribution
channels and a decrease in the travel agent commission cap from $50 to
$20, effective August&nbsp;28, 2001, also contributed to the decrease.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Aircraft maintenance materials and repairs expense per ASM increased
2.0% due primarily to the deferral of certain aircraft C-Check expenses
($3.1&nbsp;million) in the post-September&nbsp;11 period and the reduction in
ASMs.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Depreciation and amortization expense per ASM increased 18.8% due
primarily to an increase in amortization expense related to aircraft
leasehold improvements ($2.8&nbsp;million) and computer software and hardware
additions and facility improvements to support growth ($1.6&nbsp;million).
Higher depreciation expense related to rotable aircraft parts ($2.3
million) and owned aircraft ($1.6&nbsp;million) also contributed to the
increase.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Amortization of excess reorganization value expense per ASM increased
due to the 2.1% decrease in ASMs.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">28</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>




<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Other operating expenses per ASM decreased 7.6% to 1.68 cents from
1.82 cents primarily due to lower interrupted trip and baggage claim
expenses as a result of AWA&#146;s improved operating performance ($19.9
million) and decreased discretionary spending which drove lower
advertising ($9.2&nbsp;million) and catering ($3.8&nbsp;million) costs. The
recovery of $11.0&nbsp;million from the settlement in March 2001 of a lawsuit
related to an air-to-ground telecommunication system that was previously
written off, an $8.8&nbsp;million insurance settlement in the fourth quarter
of 2001 and a $9.0&nbsp;million charge in the fourth quarter of 2000 related
to the write-down to net realizable value of certain excess expendable
aircraft parts also contributed to the decrease. These decreases were
offset in part by higher costs related to traffic liability and other
insurance ($9.4&nbsp;million) and security services ($5.0&nbsp;million).</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Excluding the $108.2&nbsp;million of federal government assistance, AWA had net
nonoperating, pretax expenses of $11.1&nbsp;million in 2001 as compared to $27.9
million of net nonoperating, pretax income in 2000. The year-over-year change
was due primarily to a $15.5&nbsp;million gain on sale of 500,000 warrants to
purchase common stock of Priceline.com and an $8.6&nbsp;million gain on sale of one
million shares of GetThere.com common stock in 2000. Net interest expense
increased $10.9&nbsp;million in 2001 primarily due to higher average outstanding
debt. Interest income decreased $1.1&nbsp;million due to lower interest rates and
cash and cash equivalent balances in 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Government Guaranteed Loan and Related Restructuring</I></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380
million government loan guarantee. Completion of the government loan and
related restructuring increased the Company&#146;s liquidity
by approximately $390&nbsp;million ($429&nbsp;million loan, less 550 basis point
first year guarantee fee to the U.S. Treasury Department and other loan
participants, and less other transaction fees). In addition, in connection
with the completion of the government guaranteed loan, AWA restructured its
senior secured credit facility, its aircraft purchase commitments and aircraft
leases, issued $104.5&nbsp;million of 7.5% convertible notes, issued warrants to
purchase up to 18.8&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;B common stock and received
certain financing from the State of Arizona and City of Phoenix. Primarily
related to this restructuring, the Company recorded a pre-tax special charge of
$21.1&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2002. Components of the special charge
are as follows:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="82%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="4%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><FONT size="1"><B>Special Charges</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="3"><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="center" colspan="3"><FONT size="1"><B>(In thousands)</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#eeeeee">
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Fleet restructuring costs</FONT></DIV></TD>

    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Severance</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Revision of estimate for second quarter 2001 special charge</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">(4,000</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap><FONT size="2">)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#eeeeee">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Total</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">21,055</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="4" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Of the special charge amount, approximately $10.3&nbsp;million, principally
related to losses on sale-leaseback transactions, fleet restructuring costs,
professional fees and severance, had not been paid and was therefore accrued as
of March&nbsp;31, 2002. In the third quarter of 2002, AWA recorded a $2.0&nbsp;million
reduction in special charges for fleet restructuring costs due to a revision of
the estimated costs related to early termination of certain aircraft leases.
As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, approximately $5.8&nbsp;million of the accrued special
charges for 2002 and prior periods remained unpaid. Approximately $2.5&nbsp;million
related to estimated losses on sale-leaseback transactions is expected to be
paid by the fourth quarter of 2003. Approximately $3.3&nbsp;million of fleet
restructuring costs, primarily related to rent payments for grounded aircraft,
is expected to be paid through the fourth quarter of 2005.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We expect to fund accrued special charges from funds provided by
operations, existing cash balances and future financings, if necessary. See
&#147;<I>Commitments</I>&#148; below for a discussion of our future cash commitments and Note 4,
&#147;<I>Government Guaranteed Loan</I>&#148; and Note 14, &#147;<I>Special Charges</I>&#148; in Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements for a further discussion of the government
guaranteed loan, the related restructuring and special charges incurred in 2001
and 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Sources and Uses of Cash</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2002, Holdings&#146; and AWA&#146;s unrestricted cash and cash
equivalents and short-term investments were $360.5&nbsp;million and $351.4&nbsp;million,
respectively. Net cash used in operating activities for Holdings and AWA was
$22.9&nbsp;million and $24.3&nbsp;million, respectively, in 2002. This compares to
$152.4&nbsp;million and $147.9&nbsp;million of
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">29</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">net cash provided by operating activities
for Holdings and AWA, respectively, in 2001. The year-over-year decrease in
net cash provided by operating activities of $175.2&nbsp;million and $172.2&nbsp;million
for Holdings and AWA, respectively, was due primarily to a higher loss in the
2002 period and payment in the 2002 period of amounts due vendors and aircraft
lessors that had been subject to the Company&#146;s cash conservation program prior
to the closing of the government loan in January 2002. During 2002, the
Company paid $58.1&nbsp;million of transportation taxes to the IRS that had been
deferred from 2001, as allowed under the Air Transportation Safety and System
Stabilization Act. The Company also benefited from a $60.3&nbsp;million federal
income tax refund in 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2002, net cash used in investing activities by Holdings and AWA was
$6.3&nbsp;million and $6.0&nbsp;million, respectively. Principal investing activities
during 2002 included the purchase of two new A320 aircraft, which were
subsequently refinanced as part of a sale-leaseback transaction. The Company
also received $175.5&nbsp;million of proceeds from the sale and leaseback of one new
A319 aircraft and four new A320 aircraft and purchased short-term investments
totaling $70.0&nbsp;million. The 2001 period included the purchase of 11 new A319
aircraft and two new A320 aircraft. Ten of these aircraft were subsequently
refinanced in 2001 as the result of sale-leaseback transactions, resulting in
$332.8&nbsp;million of proceeds to
AWA. The remaining three aircraft were refinanced in 2002 as the result
of the $175.5&nbsp;million sale-leaseback transaction discussed above. The 2001
period also included $27.4&nbsp;million of proceeds from the sale and leaseback of
two owned aircraft engines and three flight simulators and sales of short-term
investments totaling $50.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2002, net cash provided by financing activities by Holdings and AWA was
$208.1&nbsp;million and $208.4&nbsp;million, respectively, primarily due to the
government guaranteed loan discussed below. The Company also repaid $161.2
million of debt as a result of the sale and leaseback of the five aircraft
discussed above and paid $37.0&nbsp;million in loan-related fees during 2002. In
addition, AWA made a mandatory repayment of approximately $16.7&nbsp;million on its
$89.9&nbsp;million term loan. The payment was made as a result of a decrease in the
fair market value of the assets securing the loan following the terrorist
attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001. Collateral for the loan consists of aircraft,
spare engines, rotable aircraft parts inventory and a maintenance facility.
AWA and the lenders also amended certain provisions in the loan agreement
related to the collateral appraisal procedures. See Note 7, <I>&#147;Long-Term Debt&#148;</I>
in Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. During 2001, AWA borrowed
$378.4&nbsp;million from its 2001-1 and 2000-1 Pass-Through Trusts to fund the
acquisition of the 13 new aircraft above and borrowed $45.0&nbsp;million under the
Company&#146;s revolving credit facility. As a result of the sale-leaseback of the
ten aircraft discussed above, AWA repaid, or assigned to a third party on a
non-recourse basis, $281.4&nbsp;million of the amounts borrowed. In addition,
during 2001, AWA repaid $66.5&nbsp;million of indebtedness under its revolving
credit facility.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Capital expenditures for 2002 were approximately $157.2&nbsp;million for
Holdings and $156.9&nbsp;million for AWA. Included in these amounts are capital
expenditures for capitalized maintenance of approximately $118.7&nbsp;million.
Capital expenditures for 2003 are expected to increase to approximately $200
million due to increased capitalized maintenance for engines that were
previously covered under warranty. Non-maintenance capital spending will be
approximately $45&nbsp;million as, under the Company&#146;s cash conservation program,
spending continues to be limited to projects that are mandatory or have a
payback period less than one year. The Company currently intends to fund such
expenditures with cash from operations. See <I>&#147;Commitments.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of the commencement of military action in Iraq, in March 2003,
the Company announced a plan to reduce management, professional and
administrative payroll costs which will result in fewer employees within these
workgroups. In addition, the Company&#146;s business partners and vendors will be
asked to reduce their fees in order to further reduce costs and maintain
sufficient liquidity in this uncertain environment.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Pass Through Trusts</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since AWA&#146;s restructuring in 1994, AWA has set up 19 pass through trusts,
which have issued over $1.4&nbsp;billion of pass through trust certificates (also
known as &#147;Enhanced Equipment Trust Certificates&#148; or &#147;EETC&#148;). These trusts are
off-balance sheet entities, the primary purpose of which is to finance the
acquisition of aircraft. Rather than finance each aircraft separately when
such aircraft is purchased or delivered, these trusts allow the Company to
raise the financing for several aircraft at one time and place such funds in
escrow pending the purchase or delivery of the relevant aircraft.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Each trust covered a set amount of aircraft scheduled to be delivered within a
specific period of time. At the time of each covered aircraft financing, the
relevant trust used the funds in escrow to purchase equipment notes relating to
the financed aircraft. The equipment notes were issued, at AWA&#146;s election,
either by AWA in connection with a mortgage financing of the
aircraft or by a separate owner trust in connection with a leveraged lease
financing of the aircraft. In the case of a leveraged lease financing, the
owner trust then leased the aircraft to AWA. In both cases, the equipment
notes are secured by a security interest in the aircraft. The pass through
trust certificates are not
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">30</FONT>




<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">direct obligations of, nor guaranteed by, Holdings
or AWA. However, in the case of mortgage financings, the equipment notes
issued to the trusts are direct obligations of AWA and in the case of leveraged
lease financings, the leases are direct obligations of AWA. All aircraft
financed by these trusts are currently structured as leveraged lease
financings, which are not reflected as debt on the balance sheets of either AWA
or Holdings.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA&#146;s 2001-1 Pass Through Trusts provided for the financing of nine Airbus
A319 aircraft and five Airbus A320 aircraft. Of the 14 aircraft, 11 were
delivered in 2001 and three were delivered in 2002. Except for one aircraft
delivered in the first quarter of 2002, which was financed as a leveraged lease
upon delivery, the acquisition of each aircraft was initially structured as a
mortgage financing and subsequently converted into a leveraged lease financing
in sale-leaseback transactions. In connection with the purchase of two
aircraft delivered in the second quarter of 2002, AWA issued $64.2&nbsp;million of
equipment notes. In June 2002, AWA converted the mortgage financing of three
aircraft delivered in 2001 and the two aircraft delivered in the second quarter
of 2002 into leveraged lease financings by entering into sale-leaseback
transactions. As a result, approximately $161.2&nbsp;million of the equipment notes
were assumed, on a non-recourse basis, by the owner trustees that purchased the
aircraft from AWA.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Commitments</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, we had $720.1&nbsp;million of long-term debt
(including current maturities). This amount consisted primarily of the $429
million government guaranteed loan, a $73.2&nbsp;million secured term loan with a
group of financial institutions, $91.7&nbsp;million face value of convertible senior
notes and notes payable secured by certain of AWA&#146;s aircraft.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table sets forth our cash obligations as of December&nbsp;31,
2002.

    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Includes an unsecured promissory note maturing in June 2003 with a fixed
rate of 10%. In June 2002, AWA restructured the leases for six of its
Boeing 757-200 aircraft to improve lease rental rates and other terms.
Prior to the restructuring, AWA subleased the six aircraft from The Boeing
Company (&#147;Boeing&#148;), who in turn leased
the aircraft from five different head lessors. Under the restructuring,
AWA terminated the subleases with Boeing and assumed, amended and restated
the existing head leases for each aircraft. Upon closing of the
transactions, AWA paid approximately $11.8&nbsp;million in security deposits and
advance rental payments to the head lessors, net of a refund from Boeing
for prorated prepaid rent under the subleases, prorated accrued rent under
the head leases and cash deposits for the estimated cost of certain
maintenance work required to be performed on the aircraft prior to their
return to Boeing. As a result of these transactions, Boeing also
relinquished its interest in approximately $11.2&nbsp;million face value of 7.5%
convertible notes it received as compensation for certain concessions
granted under the restructuring completed on January&nbsp;18, 2002.
Furthermore, AWA issued a $4.9&nbsp;million note payable to Boeing for the value
of the concessions realized with respect to these six aircraft prior to the
termination of the subleases, of which approximately $2.5&nbsp;million was paid
in 2002. The restructured leases have a remaining term of approximately
six years.</FONT></TD>

engines for delivery in 2003 through 2007.</FONT></TD>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We expect to fund these cash obligations from funds provided by
operations, the proceeds of the government guaranteed loan, the financing
commitments for Airbus aircraft obtained in connection with the government
loan, and future financings, if necessary. The cash available to us from these
sources, however, may not be sufficient to cover these cash obligations because
economic factors outside our control may reduce the amount of cash generated by
operations or increase our costs. For instance, a further economic downturn or
other events, including the commencement of hostilities against Iraq, could
reduce the demand for air travel, which would reduce the amount of cash
generated by operations. An increase in borrowing costs, either due to a
reduction in our credit rating or due to a general increase in interest rates,
or in the cost of fuel, maintenance, aircraft and aircraft engines and parts,
could increase our costs, which could decrease the amount of cash available to
cover the cash obligations. In addition, we may be required to prepay portions
of the government guaranteed loan if our employee compensation costs exceed a
certain threshold; we may be required to prepay portions of the term loan to
the extent the value of the collateral securing the term loan decreases; and we
may fail to meet the minimum liquidity threshold required to obtain the entire
amount of financing commitment for two of the Airbus aircraft. In any of these
cases, our liquidity may be adversely affected and we may not have sufficient
cash to prepay the government loan and meet our other obligations. Moreover,
certain of our long-term debt agreements
contain a $100&nbsp;million minimum cash balance requirement. As a result, we
cannot use all of our available cash to fund operations, capital expenditures
and cash obligations without violating this requirement.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although there can be no assurances, we believe that cash flow from
operating activities coupled with existing cash balances and financing
commitments will be adequate to fund our operating and capital needs as well as
enable us to maintain compliance with our various debt agreements through at
least December&nbsp;31, 2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Financial Covenants and Credit Rating</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to the minimum cash balance requirements, our long-term debt
agreements contain various negative covenants that restrict our actions,
including our ability to pay dividends, together with any other restricted
payments. Moreover, under the terms of the government guaranteed loan, we are
prohibited from paying cash dividends prior to repayment of the loan in full.
Finally, our long-term debt agreements contain cross-default provisions, which
may be triggered by defaults by us under other agreements relating to
indebtedness. As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, we had suspended payment under certain
aircraft leases and, as a result, had received notices of default from certain
aircraft lessors. In January 2002, we paid in full approximately $81&nbsp;million in
deferred aircraft lease payments simultaneously with the funding of the $429
million loan supported by a $380&nbsp;million government loan guarantee, thereby
curing the defaults. See <I>&#147;Risk Factors Relating to America West and Industry
Related Risks</I>
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">32</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our high level of debt and fixed costs limits our ability to
fund general corporate requirements, limits our flexibility in responding to
competitive developments and increases our vulnerability to adverse economic
and industry conditions.&#148; </I>As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, Holdings and AWA were in
compliance with the covenants in their long-term debt agreements
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2002, Standard &#038; Poor&#146;s raised its credit ratings on Holdings to
B- from CCC- and AWA for its senior unsecured debt to CCC from C and removed
them from Credit Watch, where they were placed on September&nbsp;13, 2001. Ratings
on the various pass-through certificates were also raised. However, the
outlook on the industry and AWA continues to be negative. Moody&#146;s currently
rates AWA&#146;s senior unsecured debt at Ca. Our relatively low credit ratings may
impair our ability to incur additional indebtedness. The rating agencies base
their ratings on our financial performance and operations, our cash flow and
liquidity, the level of our debt and industry conditions in general. If our
financial performance or industry conditions do not improve, we may face future
downgrades, which could further negatively impact our borrowing costs and the
prices of our equity or debt securities. See <I>&#147;Risk Factors Relating to America
West and Industry Related Risks &#151; Because of our relatively low credit ratings,
our borrowing costs may be high and our ability to incur additional debt may be
impaired.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Other Information</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Labor Relations</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On December&nbsp;23, 2002, the Company announced that it had reached a
tentative agreement with the Air Line Pilots Association (&#147;ALPA&#148;) on a new
contract for AWA&#146;s pilots. The tentative agreement was subject to a membership
ratification vote in March 2003. On March&nbsp;18, 2003, ALPA informed the Company
that a majority of AWA&#146;s pilots voted against ratification of the tentative
agreement. The Company will resume mediated discussions with ALPA at a date to
be determined by the National Mediation Board (&#147;NMB&#148;). The Company cannot
predict the outcome of those discussions.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, the Company is in negotiations with the International
Brotherhood of Teamsters (&#147;IBT&#148;) on a first contract covering the Company&#146;s
stock clerks, a work group of approximately 50 employees. The parties are
currently in mediation under the auspices of the NMB. The Company cannot
predict the form of this future collective bargaining agreement and therefore
the effect, if any, on AWA&#146;s operations or financial performance.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On August&nbsp;19, 2002, the IBT filed an Application for Investigation of
Representation Dispute with the NMB, seeking to represent approximately 4,000
passenger service representatives and reservations agents.
An election was conducted and on November&nbsp;12, 2002, the NMB dismissed the
case, finding that the majority of employees (2,051 of 3,619) chose not to be
represented by a union. Thereafter, the IBT appealed the election results
claiming the Company improperly interfered with the employees&#146; voting rights.
The Company vigorously denied any wrongdoing and the matter is currently being
investigated by the NMB. The Company cannot predict the outcome of the
investigation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Income Taxes</I></B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company had net operating loss carryforwards
(&#147;NOL&#148;), business tax credit carryforwards and alternative minimum tax credit
carryforwards for federal income tax purposes of approximately $399.6&nbsp;million,
$1.9&nbsp;million and $1.2&nbsp;million, respectively. The NOL expire during the years
2007 through 2009 while the business credit carryforwards expire during the
years 2003 through 2006. However, such carryforwards are not available to
offset federal (and in certain circumstances, state) alternative minimum
taxable income. Further, as a result of a statutory &#147;ownership change&#148; (as
defined for purposes of Section&nbsp;382 of the Internal Revenue Code) that occurred
as a result of the Company&#146;s reorganization in 1994, the Company&#146;s ability to
utilize its NOL and business tax credit carryforwards may be restricted. The
alternative minimum tax credit may be carried forward without expiration and is
available to offset future income tax payable to the extent regular income tax
exceeds alternative minimum tax in any given year.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s reorganization and the associated implementation of fresh
start reporting in 1994 gave rise to significant items of expense for financial
reporting purposes that are not deductible for income tax purposes. In large
measure, it is these nondeductible expenses that result in an effective tax
expense (benefit)&nbsp;rate for financial reporting purposes that differs from the
current federal statutory income tax rate of 35% for the years ended December
31, 2001 and 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">33</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Government Regulations</I></B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On November&nbsp;19, 2001, the President signed into law the Aviation and
Transportation Security Act (the &#147;ATSA&#148;). This law enhances aviation security
measures and federalizes many aspects of civil aviation security. ATSA
established a new Transportation Security Administration within the Department
of Transportation. Under the ATSA, all security screeners at airports will be
federal employees and a significant number of other airport security functions
will be overseen and performed by federal employees, including federal security
managers, federal law enforcement officers and federal air marshals. The ATSA
mandated that beginning on January&nbsp;18, 2002, all checked baggage at United
States airports be screened using explosive detection systems, or, where such
systems are not yet available, using other screening techniques such as
positively matching baggage to a passenger who has boarded an aircraft. The
ATSA requires all checked baggage to be screened by explosive detection systems
by December&nbsp;31, 2003. Other requirements in the ATSA that directly affect
airline operations include: the strengthening of cockpit doors; deploying
federal air marshals on board certain flights; improving airline crew security
training; and expanding use of criminal background checks of employees.
Implementation of these and other requirements of the ATSA will result in
increased costs for air carriers and may result in delays and disruptions to
air travel. Under the ATSA, funding for the new federal security system is to
be provided by a $2.50 per enplanement ticket tax, not to exceed $5.00 per
one-way trip, and by imposing additional direct fees on air carriers. Pursuant
to the ATSA, air carriers began collecting the new ticket tax from passengers
on February&nbsp;1, 2002 and have been required to make additional payments to the
Transportation Security Administration. The total estimated cost to the
Company of compliance with the security requirements of the ATSA for 2003 is
approximately $16.6&nbsp;million. As a result of competitive pressure, AWA and
other airlines may be unable to recover all of these additional security costs
from passengers through increased fares. In addition, we cannot forecast what
new security and safety requirements may be imposed in the future or the costs
or financial impact of complying with any such requirements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 1997, new aviation taxes were imposed through September&nbsp;30, 2007 to
provide funding for the Federal Aviation Administration (&#147;FAA&#148;). Included in
the new law is a phase-in of a modified federal air
transportation excise tax structure with a system that includes: a
domestic excise tax which started at 9% and declined to 7.5% in 1999; a
domestic segment tax that started at $1.00 and increases to $3.00 by 2003; and
an increase in taxes imposed on international travel from $6.00 per
international departure to an arrival and departure tax of $12.00 (each way).
Both the domestic segment tax and the international arrival and departure tax
are indexed for inflation. The legislation also included a 7.5% excise tax on
certain amounts paid to an air carrier for the right to provide mileage and
similar awards (e.g., purchase of frequent flyer miles by a credit card
company). As a result of competitive pressures, AWA and other airlines have
been limited in their ability to pass on the cost of these taxes to passengers
through fare increases.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Congress will be reviewing FAA funding in 2003 which may result in changes
to the current funding mechanisms. AWA cannot currently estimate the effect
any new combination of ticket and segment taxes, or any change in those taxes
will have on its operating results. There can be no assurance that any changes
will not have a material adverse effect on AWA&#146;s financial condition and
results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For additional information on government regulation and its effect on the
Company see <I>&#147;Government Regulations&#148; </I>in Item&nbsp;1, Business.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Related Party Transactions</I></B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As part of our reorganization in 1994, Continental Airlines and AWA
entered into an alliance agreement which included code sharing arrangements,
reciprocal frequent flyer programs and ground handling operations. In March
2002, AWA received notice from Continental of its intention to terminate the
code sharing and frequent flyer agreements between the two airlines, effective
April&nbsp;26, 2002. Two of Continental&#146;s directors are managing partners of Texas
Pacific Group, which, through TPG Advisors, Inc., effectively controls the
voting power of Holdings. See <I>&#147;Risk Factors Relating to America West and
Industry Related Risks  &#151; The stockholders who effectively control the voting
power of Holdings could take actions that would favor their own personal
interests to the detriment of our interests.&#148; </I>AWA paid Continental
approximately $25.5&nbsp;million, $30.1&nbsp;million and $32.4&nbsp;million and also received
approximately $15.9&nbsp;million, $22.0&nbsp;million and $25.5&nbsp;million in 2002, 2001 and
2000, respectively, from Continental pursuant to these agreements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA provides air transportation and certain administrative services to The
Leisure Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Holdings that was formed on
January&nbsp;1, 1998. The cost of air transportation and administrative services
are negotiated on an arms length basis. AWA had net air transportation sales
to TLC of $44.5&nbsp;million, $60.2&nbsp;million and $55.3&nbsp;million, respectively, in
2002, 2001 and 2000 and also received $1.3&nbsp;million in each of
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">34</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">those years under
the services agreement.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Critical Accounting Policies</I></B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The preparation of our consolidated financial statements in accordance
with generally accepted accounting principles requires that we make certain
estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets and
liabilities, revenues and expenses, and the disclosure of contingent assets and
liabilities at the date of our financial statements. We believe our estimates
and assumptions are reasonable; however, actual results could differ from those
estimates. We have identified the following critical accounting policies that
require the use of significant judgments and estimates relating to matters that
are inherently uncertain and may result in materially different results under
different assumptions and conditions.
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Passenger Revenue &#150; Passenger revenue is recognized when
transportation is provided. Ticket sales for transportation that has
not yet been provided are recorded as air traffic liability. Passenger
traffic commissions and related fees are expensed when the related
revenue is recognized. Passenger traffic commissions and related fees
not yet recognized are included as a prepaid expense. Due to complex
pricing structures, refund and exchange policies, and interline
agreements with other airlines, certain amounts are recognized in
revenue using estimates regarding both the timing of the revenue
recognition and the amount of revenue to be recognized. These estimates
are generally based on the statistical analysis of our historical data.
Any adjustments
resulting from periodic evaluations of the estimated air traffic liability
are included in results of operations during the period in which the
evaluations are completed.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Accounting For Long-Lived Assets &#150; Owned property and equipment are
recorded at cost and depreciated to residual values over the estimated
useful lives using the straight-line method. Leasehold improvements
relating to flight equipment and other property on operating leases are
amortized over the life of the lease, or the life of the asset,
whichever is shorter. Interest on advance payments for aircraft
acquisitions and on expenditures for aircraft improvements is
capitalized and added to the cost of the asset. The estimated useful
lives of our owned aircraft, jet engines, flight equipment and rotable
parts range from five to 30&nbsp;years. The estimated useful lives of our
technical support facility and flight training center in Phoenix,
Arizona are 22&nbsp;years and 30&nbsp;years, respectively. The estimated useful
lives of our ground property and equipment range from three to 12&nbsp;years.
We test for impairment losses on long-lived assets used in operations
when events and circumstances indicate that the assets might be impaired
as defined by SFAS No.&nbsp;144, <I>&#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal
of Long-Lived Assets.&#148; </I>An impairment loss is recognized if the carrying
amount of the asset is not recoverable from its undiscounted cash flows
and is measured as the difference between the carrying amount and fair
value of the asset.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Frequent Flyer Accounting &#150; We maintain a frequent travel award
program known as &#147;FlightFund&#148; that provides a variety of awards to
program members based on accumulated mileage. The estimated cost of
providing the free travel is recognized as a liability and charged to
operations as program members accumulate mileage. Travel awards are
valued at the incremental cost of carrying one passenger, based on
expected redemptions. Incremental costs are based on expectations of
expenses to be incurred on a per passenger basis and include fuel,
liability insurance, food, beverages, supplies and ticketing costs. We
also sell mileage credits to companies participating in our FlightFund
program, such as hotels, car rental agencies and credit card companies.
Transportation-related revenue from the sale of mileage credits is
deferred and recognized when transportation is provided. A change to
the estimated cost per mile, minimum award level, percentage of revenue
to be deferred or deferred recognition period could have a significant
impact on our revenues or mileage liability accrual in the year of the
change as well as future years.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Long-Term Maintenance Reserve &#150; We record an accrual for the
estimated cost of scheduled airframe and engine overhauls required to be
performed on leased aircraft upon their return to the lessors. These
estimates are based on historical costs and our assumptions regarding
the renewal of aircraft leases. A significant change to the Airline&#146;s
fleet plan could have a material impact on our reserve requirements.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements</I></B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April 2002, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued
SFAS No.&nbsp;145, &#147;<I>Rescission of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;4, 44, and 64, Amendment of
FASB Statement No.&nbsp;13, and Technical Corrections as of April 2002</I>.&#148; This
standard rescinds SFAS No.&nbsp;4, &#147;<I>Reporting Gains and Losses from Extinguishment
of Debt</I>,&#148; and an amendment of that Statement, SFAS No.&nbsp;64, &#147;<I>Extinguishments of
Debt Made to Satisfy Sinking-Fund Requirements</I>&#148; and excludes extraordinary item
treatment for gains and losses associated with the extinguishment of debt that
do not meet the Accounting Principles Board (&#147;APB&#148;) Opinion No.&nbsp;30, &#147;<I>Reporting
the Results of Operations &#151; Reporting</I>
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">35</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>the Effects of Disposal of a Segment of
a Business, and Extraordinary, Unusual and Infrequently Occurring Events and
Transactions</I>&#148; criteria. Any gain or loss on extinguishment of debt that was
classified as an extraordinary item in prior periods presented that does not
meet the criteria in APB No.&nbsp;30 for classification as an extraordinary item
shall be reclassified. SFAS No.&nbsp;145 also amends SFAS No.&nbsp;13, &#147;<I>Accounting for
Leases,</I>&#148; as well as other existing authoritative pronouncements to make various
technical corrections, clarify meanings, or describe their applicability under
changed conditions. AWA adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;145 effective January&nbsp;1, 2002 with no
material impact on its financial condition or results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;146, &#147;<I>Accounting for Costs
Associated with Exit or Disposal Activities</I>.&#148; This standard addresses
financial accounting and reporting for costs associated with exit or disposal
activities and replaces Emerging Issues Task Force (&#147;EITF&#148;) Issue No.&nbsp;94-3,
&#147;<I>Liability Recognition for Certain Employee Termination Benefits and Other
Costs to Exit an Activity (including Certain Costs Incurred in a
Restructuring.</I>)&#148; SFAS No.&nbsp;146 requires that a liability for costs associated
with an exit or disposal activity be recognized when the liability is incurred.
Under EITF No.&nbsp;94-3, a liability for exit costs, as defined in EITF No.&nbsp;94-3,
was recognized at the date of an entity&#146;s commitment to an exit plan. The
provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;146 are effective for exit or disposal activities that
are initiated by AWA after December&nbsp;31, 2002. In February 2003, AWA announced
that it will eliminate hub operations in Columbus, Ohio. In accordance with
SFAS No.&nbsp;146, AWA expects to record pretax special charges of approximately $10
to $15&nbsp;million. See Note 21, <I>&#147;Subsequent Event &#150; Elimination of Hub Operations
in Columbus, Ohio&#148; </I>in Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November 2002, the FASB issued Interpretation (&#147;FIN&#148;) No.&nbsp;45,
<I>&#147;Guarantor&#146;s Accounting and Disclosure Requirements for Guarantees, Including
Indirect Guarantees of Indebtedness of Others.&#148; </I>FIN No.&nbsp;45 requires a
guarantor to recognize, at the inception of a guarantee, a liability for the
fair value of the obligation undertaken in issuing the guarantee. FIN No.&nbsp;45
also expands the disclosures required to be made by a guarantor about its
obligations under certain guarantees that it has issued. Initial recognition
and measurement provisions of FIN No.&nbsp;45 are applicable on a prospective basis
to guarantees issued or modified. The disclosure requirements are effective
immediately. While the Company has various indemnity obligations
included in contracts entered into in the normal course of business,
these obligations are primarily in the form of indemnities that could
result in immaterial increases of future costs, but do not represent
significant commitments or contingent liabilities of the indebtedness
of others. As a result, the Company does not expect FIN No.&nbsp;45 to have a material effect
on its financial condition or results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;148, <I>&#147;Accounting for
Stock-Based Compensation &#151; Transition and Disclosure, an amendment of SFAS No.
123.&#148; </I>SFAS No.&nbsp;148 amended SFAS No.&nbsp;123, <I>&#147;Accounting for Stock-Based
Compensation,&#148; </I>to provide alternative methods of transition for an entity that
voluntarily changes to the fair value based method of accounting for
stock-based employee compensation. It also amends the disclosure provisions of
SFAS No.&nbsp;123 to require prominent disclosure about the effects on reported net
income of an entity&#146;s accounting policy decisions with respect to stock-based
employee compensation. In addition, SFAS No.&nbsp;148 amends APB Opinion No.&nbsp;28,
<I>&#147;Interim Financial Reporting,&#148; </I>to require disclosure about those effects in
interim financial information. SFAS No.&nbsp;148 is effective for financial
statements for fiscal years ending after December&nbsp;15, 2002, including certain
amendments to required disclosures related to stock-based compensation included
in condensed financial statements for interim periods beginning after December
15, 2002. The Company has complied with the required disclosure items in SFAS
No.&nbsp;148, and is still evaluating changing to the fair value based method of
accounting for stock-based employee compensation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2003, the FASB issued FIN No.&nbsp;46, <I>&#147;Consolidation of Variable
Interest Entities.&#148; </I>FIN No.&nbsp;46 requires that companies that control another
entity through interests other than voting interests should consolidate the
controlled entity. FIN No.&nbsp;46 applies to variable interest entities created
after January&nbsp;31, 2003, and to variable interest entities in which an
enterprise obtains an interest after that date. The related disclosure
requirements are effective immediately. The Company has evaluated the
provisions of FIN 46 and does not believe it to be reasonably possible that
adoption would have a material effect on its financial condition and results of
operations.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">36</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<!-- link2 "ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="009"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Market Risk Sensitive Instruments</B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>(a)&nbsp;Commodity Price Risk</I></B></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel costs accounted for approximately 14% of the Company&#146;s total
operating expenses during 2002. At current consumption levels, a one-cent per
gallon change in the price of jet fuel would affect the Company&#146;s annual
operating results in 2003 by approximately $4.4&nbsp;million. Accordingly, a
substantial change in the price of jet fuel would have a significant impact on
the Company&#146;s results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 1996, AWA implemented a fuel hedging program to manage the risk from
fluctuating jet fuel prices. The program&#146;s objectives are to provide some
protection against extreme, upward movements in the price of jet fuel and to
protect AWA&#146;s ability to meet its annual fuel expense budget. Under the
program, AWA may enter into certain hedging transactions with approved
counterparties for future periods generally not exceeding 12&nbsp;months.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company had entered into costless collar
transactions which establish an upper and lower limit on heating oil futures
prices. These transactions are in place with respect to approximately 40% of
projected 2003 fuel requirements, including 63% related to the first quarter of
2003. In order to execute additional hedging transactions, we anticipate that
we will have to provide cash collateral or other credit support, which we may
not be able to provide in a cost-effective manner. See <I>&#147;Risk Factors Relating
to America West and Industry Related Risks &#151; Fluctuations in fuel costs could
adversely affect our operating expenses and results.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The use of such hedging transactions in the Company&#146;s fuel hedging program
could result in the Company not fully benefiting from certain declines in
heating oil futures prices. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company estimates that a
10% increase in heating oil futures prices would increase the fair value of the
costless collar transactions by approximately $4.7&nbsp;million. The Company
estimates that a 10% decrease in heating oil futures prices would decrease the
fair value of the costless collar transactions by approximately $1.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of March&nbsp;31, 2003, approximately 40% of AWA&#146;s 2003 projected fuel
requirements are hedged.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>(b)&nbsp;Interest Rate Risk</I></B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s exposure to interest rate risk relates primarily to its
variable rate long-term debt obligations. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company&#146;s
variable-rate long-term debt obligations of approximately $554&nbsp;million
represented approximately 78% of its total long-term debt. If interest rates
increased 10% in 2003, the impact on the Company&#146;s results of operations would
not be material.
</FONT>
<!-- link2 "ITEM 8A. CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTARY DATA &#151; AMERICA &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="010"></A></DIV>

the three-year period ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, together with the related notes
and the reports of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, independent accountants, and
KPMG LLP, independent auditors, are set forth on the following pages.

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTANTS</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>The Board of Directors and Stockholders<BR>
of America West Holdings Corporation:</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In our opinion, the accompanying consolidated balance sheets and the
related consolidated statements of operations, of cash flows and of
stockholders&#146; equity and comprehensive income (loss)&nbsp;present fairly, in all
material respects, the financial position of America West Holdings Corporation
at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, and the results of its operations and its cash
flows for the years then ended in conformity with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States of America. These financial statements
are the responsibility of the Company&#146;s management; our responsibility is to
express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits. We
conducted our audits of these statements in accordance with auditing standards
generally accepted in the United States of America, which require that we plan
and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the
financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes
examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in
the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and
significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial
statement presentation. We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis
for our opinion.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As more
fully described in Note 2, the Company has restated its financial
statements for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 to reflect impairment
charges on long-lived assets.
</font>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note 3 to the consolidated
financial statements, the Company changed its method of accounting for
reorganization value in excess of amounts allocable to identifiable assets in
connection with the adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.
142, <I>&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets,&#148; </I>effective January&nbsp;1, 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP<BR>

examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(a)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">As restated &#150; See Note 2</FONT></TD>
