<P align="center"><FONT size="2">See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">43</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS
CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<BR>
DECEMBER 31, 2002, 2001 AND 2000</B>
</FONT>



<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;America West Holdings Corporation (&#147;Holdings&#148; or the &#147;Company&#148;) is a
holding company that owns all of the stock of America West Airlines, Inc.
(&#147;AWA&#148; or the &#147;Airline&#148;). AWA accounted for most of the Company&#146;s revenues and
expenses in 2002. Based on 2002 revenues and operations, AWA is the eighth
largest passenger airline in the United States with the lowest cost structure
of the eight major hub-and-spoke airlines. At the end of 2002, AWA operated a
fleet of 143 aircraft with an average fleet age of 10.1&nbsp;years and served 65
destinations in North America, including seven in Mexico and three in Canada.
Through regional alliance and code share arrangements with other airlines, AWA
served an additional 49 destinations in North America as of December&nbsp;31, 2002.
In 2002, AWA flew approximately 19.5&nbsp;million passengers and generated revenues
of approximately $2&nbsp;billion. In addition, Holdings owns all of the outstanding
stock of The Leisure Company (&#147;TLC&#148;), which sells individual and group travel
packages, including air transportation of AWA and Hawaiian Airlines, hotel
accommodations, car rentals, cruise packages and other travel products,
directly to consumers as well as through retail travel agencies in the United
States, Canada and Mexico.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since September&nbsp;11, 2001, the U.S. domestic airline industry has
experienced an unprecedented financial crisis caused by the combination of the
terrorist attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001 and soft economic conditions. In
response to these difficult industry conditions, the Company completed a
financial restructuring, introduced a business-friendly pricing structure and
lowered its cost structure in 2002. Despite these measures, the Company
expects to continue to post significant losses in 2003. The Company believes
near-term revenues will continue to be negatively impacted by the soft economic
conditions and the decline in business traffic. In addition, fuel prices have
remained and may continue to remain well above historical norms due to the
threat of and the commencement of military action against Iraq and continued
political tension in Venezuela.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company expects to fund its obligations from funds provided by
operations, the proceeds of the government guaranteed loan, the financing
commitments for Airbus aircraft obtained in connection with the government
loan, and future financings, if necessary. The cash available to the Company
from these sources, however, may not be sufficient to cover these cash
obligations because economic factors outside the Company&#146;s control may reduce
the amount of cash generated by operations or increase its costs. As noted
above, if the Company fails to generate sufficient cash from operations and
other sources, it may need to obtain additional financings to achieve its
longer term business objectives. There can be no assurance that such
financings will be available or, if available, will be at rates or prices
acceptable to the Company.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although there can be no assurances, management believes that cash flow
from operating activities coupled with existing cash balances and financing
commitments will be adequate to fund the Company&#146;s operating and capital needs
as well as enable it to maintain compliance with its various debt agreements at
least through December&nbsp;31, 2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>1. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(a)&nbsp; Basis of Presentation</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Holdings and
its wholly owned subsidiaries AWA and TLC. All significant intercompany
balances and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation. Certain
reclassifications have been made to the prior years&#146; consolidated financial
statements to conform to the current year&#146;s presentation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(b)&nbsp; Cash, Cash Equivalents and Short-term Investments</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash equivalents consist of all highly liquid debt instruments purchased
with original maturities of three months or less. Short-term investments
consist of cash invested in certain debt securities with original maturities
greater than 90&nbsp;days and less than one year. The debt securities are
classified as held to maturity and are carried at amortized cost which
approximates fair value.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(c)&nbsp; Expendable Spare Parts and Supplies</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Flight equipment expendable spare parts and supplies are valued at average
cost. An allowance for obsolescence is provided, over the estimated useful
life of the related aircraft and engines, for spare parts expected to be on
hand at the date the aircraft are retired from service. In the fourth quarter
of 2000, the Company committed to the disposal of certain excess expendable
spare parts inventory with a net book value of approximately $11.0&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">44</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">As
a result, the Company recorded an operating expense of $9.0&nbsp;million to write
down excess inventory to net realizable value.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(d)&nbsp; Property and Equipment</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property and equipment are recorded at cost. Interest capitalized on
advance payments for aircraft acquisitions and on expenditures for aircraft
improvements are part of these costs. Interest capitalized for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001, and 2000 was $3.0&nbsp;million, $12.5&nbsp;million and $9.0
million, respectively. Property and equipment is depreciated and amortized to
residual values over the estimated useful lives or the lease term, whichever is
less, using the straight-line method.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The estimated useful lives for the Company&#146;s ground property and equipment
range from three to 12&nbsp;years for owned property and equipment and up to 22
years for the technical support facility. The estimated useful lives of the
Company&#146;s owned aircraft, jet engines, flight equipment and rotable parts range
from five to 30&nbsp;years. Leasehold improvements relating to flight equipment and
other property on operating leases are amortized over the life of the lease or
the life of the asset, whichever is shorter.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company records impairment losses on long-lived assets used in
operations when events and circumstances indicate that the assets might be
impaired as defined by Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.
144, <I>&#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets.&#148;</I>
Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the
carrying amount of an asset to undiscounted future net cash flows expected to
be generated by the asset. If such assets are considered to be impaired, the
impairment to be recognized is measured by the amount by which the carrying
amount of the assets exceeds the fair value of the assets. Assets to be
disposed of are reported at the lower of the carrying amount or fair value less
cost to sell.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(e)&nbsp; Restricted Cash</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restricted cash includes cash deposits securing certain letters of credit
and surety bonds and cash held by institutions that process credit card sales
transactions.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(f)&nbsp; Aircraft Maintenance and Repairs</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Routine maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred. The
cost of major scheduled airframe, engine and certain component overhauls are
capitalized and amortized over the periods benefited and are included in
aircraft maintenance materials and repairs expense. Additionally, an accrual
for the estimated cost of scheduled airframe and engine overhauls required to
be performed on leased aircraft prior to their return to the lessors has been
recorded.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(g)&nbsp; Reorganization Value in Excess of Amounts Allocable to Identifiable
Assets (&#147;ERV&#148;)</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2001, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued
SFAS No.&nbsp;142, <I>&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets.&#148; </I>SFAS No.&nbsp;142 primarily
addresses the accounting for goodwill and intangible assets subsequent to their
acquisition. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 does not permit the amortization of goodwill as
required by Accounting Principles Board (&#147;APB&#148;) Opinion No.&nbsp;17, <I>&#147;Intangible
Assets.&#148; </I>Rather, goodwill is subject to a periodic impairment test, using a
two-step process. The first step is to identify a potential impairment. The
second step of the goodwill impairment test measures the amount of the
impairment loss, using a fair value-based approach. Under SFAS No.&nbsp;142, ERV is
reported as goodwill and accounted for in the same manner as goodwill. SFAS
No.&nbsp;142 was effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2001. Upon
adoption of this statement on January&nbsp;1, 2002, the Company recorded an
impairment loss of $208.2&nbsp;million, which was supported by an independent
valuation of the Company. The
impairment loss was recorded as the cumulative effect of a change in
accounting principle. See Note 3, &#147;<I>Adoption of New Accounting Standard.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142, ERV was amortized on a straight line
basis over 20&nbsp;years. Accumulated amortization at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000
was $178.1&nbsp;million and $156.6&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">45</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(h)&nbsp; Derivative Instruments</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA&#146;s fuel hedging contracts qualify as cash flow hedges under SFAS No.
133, <I>&#147;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities,&#148; </I>as they
hedge exposure to variable cash flows of forecasted transactions. Accordingly,
the derivative hedging instrument is recorded as an asset or liability on the
balance sheet at fair value and the effective portion of changes in the fair
value are initially recorded in <I>&#147;Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (Loss)&#148;</I>
until the underlying fuel being hedged is used. The ineffective portion of
changes in fair value are recorded in earnings.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(i)&nbsp; Frequent Flyer Awards</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company maintains a frequent travel award program known as
&#147;FlightFund&#148; that provides a variety of awards to program members based on
accumulated mileage. The estimated cost of providing the free travel, using
the incremental cost method as adjusted for estimated redemption rates, is
recognized as a liability and charged to operations as program members
accumulate mileage.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company also sells mileage credits to companies participating in its
FlightFund program, such as hotels, car rental agencies and credit card
companies. Revenue from the sale of mileage credits is deferred and recognized
when transportation is provided.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(j)&nbsp; Deferred Credits-Operating Leases</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rents for operating leases were adjusted to fair market value when the
Company emerged from bankruptcy in 1994. The net present value of the
difference between the stated lease rates and the fair market rates has been
recorded as a deferred credit in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
The deferred credit will be increased through charges to interest expense and
decreased on a straight-line basis as a reduction in rent expense over the
applicable lease periods. At December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, the unamortized
balance of the deferred credit was $52.4&nbsp;million and $58.7&nbsp;million,
respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380
million government loan guarantee. See Note 4, <I>&#147;Government Guaranteed Loan.&#148;</I>
This loan triggered aircraft rent concessions negotiated with approximately 20
aircraft lessors. Approximately $18.1&nbsp;million of aircraft rent, which was
accrued as of December&nbsp;31, 2001, was waived by the aircraft lessors. This
amount has been recorded as a deferred credit in the accompanying consolidated
balance sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and will be amortized over the remaining
lives of the applicable leases as a reduction in rent expense. At December&nbsp;31,
2002, the unamortized balance of the deferred credit was approximately $10.9
million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(k)&nbsp; Passenger Revenue</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Passenger revenue is recognized when transportation is provided. Ticket
sales for transportation which has not yet been provided are recorded as air
traffic liability. Passenger traffic commissions and related fees are expensed
when the related revenue is recognized. Passenger traffic commissions and
related fees not yet recognized are included as a prepaid expense. Due to
complex pricing structures, refund and exchange policies, and interline
agreements with other airlines, certain amounts are recognized in revenue using
estimates regarding both the timing of the revenue recognition and the amount
of revenue to be recognized.
These estimates are generally based on the statistical analysis of the
Company&#146;s historical data. Any adjustments resulting from periodic evaluations
of the estimated air traffic liability are included in results of operations
during the period in which the evaluations are completed.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(l)&nbsp; Advertising Costs</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company expenses the costs of advertising as incurred. Advertising
expense for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000 was $10.6&nbsp;million,
$13.8&nbsp;million and $26.3&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(m)&nbsp; Income Taxes</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability method.
Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax
consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement
carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax
bases and operating loss and tax credit
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">46</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">carryforwards. A valuation allowance
is established, if necessary, for the amount of any tax benefits
that, based on available evidence, are not expected to be realized.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(n)&nbsp; Stock Options</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company has two stock-based employee
compensation plans, which are described more fully in Note 11, <I>&#147;Stock Options
and Awards.&#148; </I>The Company accounts for its stock option plans in accordance
with the provisions of APB Opinion No.&nbsp;25, <I>&#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to
Employees,&#148; </I>and related interpretations. As such, compensation expense would
be recorded on the date of grant only if the current market price of the
underlying stock exceeded the exercise price. Accordingly, no compensation
cost has been recognized for stock options in the consolidated financial
statements. Had the Company determined compensation cost based on the fair
value at the grant date for its stock options under SFAS No.&nbsp;123, <I>&#147;Accounting
for Stock-Based Compensation,&#148; </I>the Company&#146;s net income (loss)&nbsp;and earnings
(loss)&nbsp;per share would have been reduced to the pro forma amounts indicated
below:
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pro forma net income (loss)&nbsp;reflects only options granted during the years
1995 through 2002. Therefore, the full impact of calculating compensation cost
for stock options under SFAS No.&nbsp;123 is not reflected in the pro forma net
income (loss)&nbsp;amounts presented above because compensation cost is reflected
over the options&#146; vesting period and compensation cost for options granted
prior to January&nbsp;1, 1995 is not considered.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(o)&nbsp; New Accounting Standards</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;145, &#147;<I>Rescission of FASB
Statements No.&nbsp;4, 44, and 64, Amendment of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;13, and Technical
Corrections as of April 2002</I>.&#148; This standard rescinds SFAS No.&nbsp;4, &#147;<I>Reporting
Gains and Losses from Extinguishment of Debt</I>,&#148; and an amendment of
that Statement, SFAS No.&nbsp;64, &#147;<I>Extinguishments of Debt Made to Satisfy
Sinking-Fund Requirements</I>&#148; and excludes extraordinary item treatment for gains
and losses associated with the extinguishment of debt that do not meet the APB
Opinion No.&nbsp;30, &#147;<I>Reporting the Results of Operation &#151; Reporting the Effects of
Disposal of a Segment of a Business, and Extraordinary, Unusual and
Infrequently Occurring Events and Transactions</I>&#148; criteria. Any gain or loss on
extinguishment of debt that was classified as an extraordinary item in prior
periods presented that does not meet the criteria in APB 30 for classification
as an extraordinary item shall be reclassified. SFAS No.&nbsp;145 also amends SFAS
No.&nbsp;13, &#147;<I>Accounting for Leases,</I>&#148; as well as other existing authoritative
pronouncements to make various technical corrections, clarify meanings, or
describe their applicability under changed conditions. The Company adopted
SFAS No.&nbsp;145 effective January&nbsp;1, 2002 with no material impact on its financial
condition or results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;146, &#147;<I>Accounting for Costs Associated
with Exit or Disposal Activities</I>.&#148; This standard addresses financial
accounting and reporting for costs associated with exit or disposal activities
and replaces EITF Issue No.&nbsp;94-3, &#147;<I>Liability Recognition for Certain Employee
Termination Benefits and Other Costs to Exit an Activity (including Certain
Costs Incurred in a Restructuring.</I>)&#148; SFAS No.&nbsp;146 requires that a liability
for costs associated with an exit or disposal activity be recognized when the
liability is incurred. Under EITF No.&nbsp;94-3, a liability for exit costs, as
defined in EITF No.&nbsp;94-3, was recognized at the date of an entity&#146;s commitment
to an exit plan. The provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;146 are effective for exit or
disposal activities that are initiated by the Company after December&nbsp;31, 2002.
In February 2003, AWA announced that it will eliminate hub
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">47</FONT>




<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">operations in Columbus, Ohio. In
accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;146, AWA expects to record pretax special charges of
approximately $10 to $15&nbsp;million. See Note 21, <I>&#147;Subsequent Event &#151; Elimination
of Hub Operations in Columbus, Ohio.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November 2002, the FASB issued Interpretation (&#147;FIN&#148;) No.&nbsp;45,
<I>&#147;Guarantor&#146;s Accounting and Disclosure Requirements for Guarantees, Including
Indirect Guarantees of Indebtedness of Others.&#148; </I>FIN 45 requires a guarantor
to recognize, at the inception of a guarantee, a liability for the fair value
of the obligation undertaken in issuing the guarantee. FIN 45 also expands the
disclosures required to be made by a guarantor about its obligations under
certain guarantees that it has issued. Initial recognition and measurement
provisions of FIN 45 are applicable on a prospective basis to guarantees issued
or modified. The disclosure requirements are effective immediately. While the
Company has various indemnity obligations included in contracts entered into in
the normal course of business, these obligations are primarily in the form of
indemnities that could result in immaterial increases of future costs, but do
not represent significant commitments or contingent liabilities of the
indebtedness of others. As a result, the Company does not expect FIN 45 to
have a material effect on its financial condition or results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;148, <I>&#147;Accounting for
Stock-Based Compensation- &#151; Transition and Disclosure, an amendment of SFAS
No.&nbsp;123.&#148; </I>SFAS No.&nbsp;148 amended SFAS No.&nbsp;123, <I>&#147;Accounting for Stock-Based
Compensation,&#148; </I>to provide alternative methods of transition for an entity that
voluntarily changes to the fair value based method of accounting for
stock-based employee compensation. It also amends the disclosure provisions of
SFAS No.&nbsp;123 to require prominent disclosure about the effects on reported net
income of an entity&#146;s accounting policy decisions with respect to stock-based
employee compensation. In addition, SFAS No.&nbsp;148 amends APB Opinion No.&nbsp;28,
<I>&#147;Interim Financial Reporting"</I>, to require disclosure about those effects in
interim financial information. SFAS No.&nbsp;148 is effective for financial
statements for fiscal years ending after December&nbsp;15, 2002, including certain
amendments to required disclosures related to stock-based compensation included
in condensed financial statements for interim periods beginning after December
15, 2002. The Company has complied with the required disclosure items in SFAS
No.&nbsp;148, and is still evaluating changing to the fair value based method of
accounting for stock-based employee compensation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2003, the FASB issued FIN No.&nbsp;46, <I>&#147;Consolidation of Variable
Interest Entities.&#148; </I>FIN 46 requires that companies that control another entity
through interests other than voting interests should consolidate the controlled
entity. FIN 46 applies to variable interest entities created after January&nbsp;31,
2003, and to variable interest entities in which an enterprise obtains an
interest after that date. The related disclosure requirements are effective
immediately. The Company has evaluated the provisions of FIN 46 and does not
believe it to be reasonably possible that adoption would have a material effect
on its financial condition and results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(p)&nbsp; Use of Estimates</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management of the Company has made certain estimates and assumptions
relating to the reporting of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of
contingent assets and liabilities to prepare these consolidated financial
statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the
United States. Actual results could differ from those estimates.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>2. Restatement of Previously Reported Amounts</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has restated its financial statements for the fiscal year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 and its unaudited financial statements for the first, second and third
quarters of fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. The changes
include:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%" align="center"><FONT size="2">&#151;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">a change in the timing from the first quarter of 2002 back
to the fourth quarter of 2001 of the non-cash impairment charge of
approximately $39.2&nbsp;million recorded to adjust the carrying value of
owned aircraft to market value and the related non-cash impairment
charge of approximately $64.1&nbsp;million recorded to write off ERV that arose in connection with the Company&#146;s plan of
reorganization from bankruptcy in 1994, both of which charges were
previously recorded in the first quarter of 2002; and</FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="3%" align="center"><FONT size="2">&#151;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">the recognition of a full valuation allowance relating to the Company&#146;s net
deferred tax assets.</FONT></TD>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">See Note 2 <I>&#147;Restatement of Previously Reported Amounts&#148; </I>in Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Impairment Charges</I></B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Statement
of Financial Standards (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.&nbsp;121
<I>&#147;Accounting for the Impairment of Long-Lived Assets and for
Long-Lived Assets to Be Disposed Of&#148;</I> requires that an
impairment analysis be performed whenever circumstances indicate that
the carrying amount of an asset that an entity expects to hold and
use may not be recoverable.</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a
result of the adverse impacts on Holdings and AWA and the airline
industry as a whole resulting from the terrorist events of
September&nbsp;11, 2001 and their aftermath, AWA performed an assessment of
impairment of its owned aircraft during 2001 and again in connection
with the preparation of the interim financial statements for the
first quarter of 2002.</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a
result of AWA&#146;s assessments, no impairment adjustment was
recorded in the financial statements previously issued for 2001. The Company
recorded an impairment charge of approximately $39.2&nbsp;million in the first
quarter of 2002 to adjust the carrying value of AWA&#146;s owned aircraft to reflect market
values at that time. Such accounting treatment was considered appropriate at
the time of the issuance of the applicable financial statements. In connection
with the preparation of the financial statements and the related
audit for the fiscal year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company determined that the more appropriate recognition of
the impairment charge of approximately $39.2&nbsp;million is in the fourth quarter
of 2001 rather than in the first quarter of 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, SFAS No.&nbsp;121 requires that goodwill that arose in a purchase
business combination be allocated, and included as part of the asset
base, in
determining recoverability and measuring impairment. The Company did not have goodwill at December&nbsp;31,
2001, but did have a significant amount of unamortized ERV. The Company has
determined that a portion of the unamortized ERV balance should have
been allocated to AWA&#146;s owned aircraft in the
impairment analysis performed for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As more fully described in Note 3, <I>&#147;Adoption of New Accounting Standard&#148;</I>
in Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, the remaining
unamortized balance of ERV was
written-off in the first quarter of 2002 as a cumulative effect of a
change in accounting principle, upon adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142,
<I>&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets.&#148;</I>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The impact of the above described matters is to change the period of
recognition for these non-cash costs between late 2001 and early 2002. See Note 19,
<I>&#147;Quarterly Financial Data (Unaudited)&#148; </I>in Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Deferred Income Taxes</I></B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS No.&nbsp;109 <I>&#147;Accounting for Income Taxes&#148; </I>requires that a valuation
allowance be established when it is &#147;more likely than not&#148; that all or a
portion of deferred tax assets will not be realized. A review of all available
positive and negative evidence needs to be considered, including the company&#146;s
performance, the market environment in which the company operates, forecasts of
future profitability, the utilization of past tax credits, length of
carryforward periods and similar factors. SFAS No.&nbsp;109 further states that it
is difficult to conclude that a valuation allowance is not needed when there is
negative evidence such as cumulative losses in recent years. Therefore,
cumulative losses weigh heavily in the overall assessment.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company had originally reported a net deferred tax liability at
December&nbsp;31, 2001. After consideration of the restatement
discussed above, the Company had a net deferred tax asset and was in a cumulative loss position for the three years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. A full valuation allowance has been established
relating to the Company&#146;s net deferred tax assets at
December&nbsp;31, 2001, and relating to
tax assets generated by losses in 2002. We expect to continue to record a full
valuation allowance on future tax benefits until we return to profitability. See Note 9, <I>&#147;Income Taxes&#148; </I>and Note 19, <I>&#147;Quarterly
Financial Data (Unaudited)&#148; </I>in Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of the adjustments discussed above, the Company&#146;s financial
statements for the first three quarters of 2002 and for the year ended 2001
have been restated from amounts previously reported. See Note 19, <I>&#147;Quarterly
Financial Data (Unaudited)&#148; </I>for a summary of the adjustments for these periods
on a quarterly basis. The principal effects of these adjustments on the
accompanying financial statements are set forth below:
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">49</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>3. Adoption of New Accounting Standard</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2001, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;142, <I>&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible
Assets.&#148; </I>SFAS No.&nbsp;142 primarily addresses the accounting for goodwill and
intangible assets subsequent to their acquisition. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 does not
permit the amortization of goodwill as required by APB Opinion No.&nbsp;17,
<I>&#147;Intangible Assets.&#148; </I>Rather, goodwill is subject to a periodic impairment
test, using a two-step process. The first step is to identify a potential
impairment. The second step of the goodwill impairment test measures the
amount of the impairment loss, using a fair value-based approach. Under SFAS
No.&nbsp;142, ERV is reported as goodwill and accounted for in the same manner as
goodwill. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 was effective for fiscal years beginning after December
15, 2001. Upon adoption of this statement on January&nbsp;1, 2002, the Company
recorded an impairment loss of $208.2&nbsp;million, which was supported by an
independent valuation of the Company. The impairment loss was recorded as the
cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table presents reported net income (loss)&nbsp;and earnings
(loss)&nbsp;per share exclusive of ERV amortization expense for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000.
</FONT>
<CENTER>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="4" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="4" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(1)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Amortization of ERV is not a tax-deductible expense.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>4. Government Guaranteed Loan</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380
million government loan guarantee. This loan triggered concessions and
additional financing (primarily aircraft rent reductions and future financing
commitments), resulting in a restructuring of AWA&#146;s indebtedness and lease
commitments. The major components of the restructuring are:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="2%" align="right" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Government Guaranteed Loan &#151; The catalyst for AWA&#146;s restructuring
plan was a $429&nbsp;million loan backed by a $380&nbsp;million federal loan
guarantee. The loan has a seven-year term with ratable amortization in
years three through seven, an interest rate of three month LIBOR plus 40
basis points paid quarterly and annual</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">50</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">guarantee fees payable to the U.S. Treasury Department and other loan
participants of 550 basis points in year one and approximately 800 basis
points thereafter.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="2%" align="right"><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Aircraft Deferrals/Financing &#151; AWA restructured its aircraft purchase
commitment with AVSA S.A.R.L., an affiliate of Airbus Industrie
(&#147;AVSA&#148;), to defer 17 new Airbus aircraft previously scheduled for
delivery in 2003 and 2004 by a total of 505 aircraft-months to 2004
through 2007. New financing commitments were obtained for 11 aircraft
which were either already delivered in 2001 or scheduled to be delivered
in 2002 and 2003. Delivery of two of these aircraft was subsequently
deferred until 2005. In order to obtain the entire amount of the
financing commitment for two of the aircraft, AWA must achieve a minimum
liquidity threshold. As a result, AWA has financing commitments for all
scheduled aircraft deliveries through the fourth quarter of 2003.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="2%" align="right"><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Aircraft Returns/Rent Reductions &#151; Through negotiations with
approximately 20 aircraft lessors, AWA has retired 11 aircraft in 2001
and 2002 to better size its fleet to the current industry demand
environment. For the aircraft that remain, annual rent payments have
been reduced for each of the next six years.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="2%" align="right"><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Term-out of Line of Credit &#151; AWA&#146;s $89.9&nbsp;million secured credit
facility was converted into an $89.9&nbsp;million secured term loan maturing
at year-end 2007. The loan has a six-year term with ratable amortization
in years four through six and an interest rate of one month LIBOR plus
225 basis points from the closing date through December&nbsp;31, 2004 and one
month LIBOR plus 475 basis points from January&nbsp;1, 2005 and thereafter.
In addition, AWA will pay interest in kind on the aggregate outstanding
principal amount of the loan at a rate of two percent per annum from the
closing date through December&nbsp;31, 2004. In July 2002, AWA made a
mandatory repayment of approximately $16.7&nbsp;million on the term loan as a
result of a decrease in the fair market value of the assets securing the
loan following the terrorist attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="2%" align="right"><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">State/City Financing &#151; From the State of Arizona and the City of
Phoenix, AWA received $0.7&nbsp;million in job training grants and $1.5
million in other financing. In March 2003, AWA received $6.9&nbsp;million
through the sale and leaseback of jetways at Phoenix Sky Harbor
International Airport.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="2%" align="right"><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">TPG Undertaking &#151; At the request of the Air Transportation
Stabilization Board (&#147;ATSB&#148;), TPG Partners, L.P., and its affiliates,
owners of all 941,431 shares of America West Holdings Class&nbsp;A common
stock, have undertaken not to dispose of their Class&nbsp;A stock other than
in connection with an offer to acquire all the shares of the Company&#146;s
Class&nbsp;B common stock accepted or approved by the holders of a majority of
the Class&nbsp;B stock. This undertaking is subject to certain exceptions,
including transfers to TPG affiliates, repurchase of the Class&nbsp;A stock by
Holdings and exercise of &#145;PG&#146;s rights to convert the Class&nbsp;A stock into
Class&nbsp;B stock, and will terminate when the warrants issued in connection
with the term loan transactions discussed below expire or are exercised
and the underlying shares of Class&nbsp;B stock are sold, or TPG and its
affiliates no longer hold the Class&nbsp;A stock.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="2%" align="right"><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Warrants/Convertible Senior Notes &#151; As compensation for various
elements of the restructuring plan, Holdings issued a warrant to purchase
up to 18.8&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;B common stock to the federal
government and additional warrants to purchase up to 3.8&nbsp;million shares
of its Class&nbsp;B common stock to other loan participants, in each case at
an exercise price of $3 per share and a term of ten years. For
accounting purposes, the warrants were valued at $35.4&nbsp;million, or $1.57
per share, using the Black-Scholes pricing model with the following
assumptions: expected dividend yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest rate of
4.8%, volatility of 44.9% and an expected life of ten years. Holdings
also issued approximately $104.5&nbsp;million in convertible senior notes as
partial compensation to aircraft lessors. The notes have a seven-year
term and a coupon rate of 7.5% with interest paid in kind for years one
through three. The notes are convertible after three years into Class&nbsp;B
common stock at $12 per share. During 2002, one aircraft lessor
relinquished its interest in approximately $11.8&nbsp;million face value of
the 7.5% convertible notes upon the restructuring of leases for six
Boeing 757-200 aircraft. One aircraft lessor also relinquished its
interest in approximately $1.6&nbsp;million face value of the 7.5% convertible
notes upon the exercise of its put rights to extend the leases for two
Boeing 737-300 aircraft.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the restructuring, Holdings and AWA granted to the
recipients of the notes and warrants certain registration rights. In May 2002,
Holdings and AWA filed a registration statement with the Securities and
Exchange Commission to satisfy their obligations to the recipients of the notes
and warrants. The registration statement covers:
</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financial Instruments and Risk Management Fair Value of Financial
Instruments</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Cash Equivalents, Short-term Investments and Receivables</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The carrying amount approximates fair value because of the short-term
nature of these instruments.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Investments in Equity Securities</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May 2000, Holdings completed the sale of a majority interest in TLC&#146;s
retail operations, National Leisure Group and The Vacation Store, to Softbank
Capital Partners and General Catalyst LLC. TLC received $52&nbsp;million in cash
and retained a 12% passive ownership interest in the restructured venture. In
response to additional capital calls, TLC invested an additional $1.2&nbsp;million
in National Leisure Group during 2001. The investment is carried on the
Company&#146;s consolidated balance sheet at cost, which approximates $7.7&nbsp;million
at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company owned approximately 28,300 shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock of
Aeroxchange Ltd., an airline industry business-to-business e-commerce exchange,
at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001. The common stock of Aeroxchange is not publicly
traded on a securities exchange, therefore the fair value of the Company&#146;s
investment in Aeroxchange is not readily determinable. Accordingly, the
investment was carried at cost, which approximated $2.8&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31,
2001. In March 2002, the Company wrote down its investment in Aeroxchange to
net realizable value, recognizing a pretax loss of $2.8&nbsp;million. See Note 15,
<I>&#147;Nonoperating Income (Expenses) &#151; Other, Net.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Warrants</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is the holder of warrants in a number of on-line ventures that
are not public. The fair value of these warrants is not readily determinable.
Accordingly, the investments are carried at cost, which was not material at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 or 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Long-term Debt</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, the fair value of long-term debt was
approximately $657.9&nbsp;million and $324.4&nbsp;million, respectively. The Company&#146;s
long-term debt with a carrying value of $570.4&nbsp;million and $179.7&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, respectively, approximates fair value because these
borrowings have variable interest
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">52</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">rate terms that approximate market interest rates for similar debt
instruments. The fair values of the Company&#146;s other long-term debt are
determined based on quoted market prices if available or market prices for
comparable debt instruments.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>(b)&nbsp; Fuel Price Risk Management</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under its fuel hedging program, the Company may enter into certain hedging
transactions with approved counterparties for a period generally not exceeding
12&nbsp;months. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company had entered into costless
collar transactions hedging approximately 40% of its projected 2003 fuel
requirements. The fair value of the Company&#146;s financial derivative instruments
was a net asset of approximately $3.6&nbsp;million and $2.2&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31,
2002 and 2001, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is exposed to credit risks in the event any counterparty fails
to meet its obligations. The Company does not anticipate such non-performance
as counterparties are selected based on credit ratings, exposure to any one
counterparty is limited based on formal guidelines and the relative market
positions with such counterparties are closely monitored.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>(c)&nbsp; Concentration of Credit Risk</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company does not believe it is subject to any significant
concentration of credit risk. Most of the Company&#146;s receivables result from
tickets sold to individual passengers through the use of major credit cards or
from tickets sold by other airlines and used by passengers on AWA. These
receivables are short-term, generally being settled shortly after the sale.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>7. Long-Term Debt</B>
</FONT>

2.94%, installments due 2003 through 2008</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">58,126</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">79,360</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(a)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In December 1999, AWA entered into a $125&nbsp;million senior secured
revolving credit facility with a group of financial institutions that had
a three-year term. Borrowings under this credit facility accrued interest
at either the &#147;base rate&#148; (prime rate or the rate which 1/21/2 of 1% in
excess of the Federal Funds Effective Rate) or the &#147;adjusted eurodollar
rate&#148; (LIBOR rate adjusted for certain reserve requirements in respect to
&#147;Eurodollar liabilities&#148;) plus the applicable margin based on Moody&#146;s
rating of AWA&#146;s senior unsecured notes. The credit agreement was secured
by certain assets of AWA. As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, AWA had drawn $89.9
million against its available line of credit which was classified in
current maturities of long-term debt in the Company&#146;s consolidated balance
sheet. In January 2002, upon closing of the $429&nbsp;million loan supported
by a $380&nbsp;million government loan guarantee (see Note 4, &#147;Government
Guaranteed Loan&#148;), AWA&#146;s secured credit facility was converted into an
$89.9&nbsp;million secured term loan maturing at year-end 2007. The loan has a
six-year term with ratable amortization in years four through six and an
interest rate of one month LIBOR plus 225 basis points from the closing
date through December&nbsp;31, 2004 and one month LIBOR plus 475 basis points
from January&nbsp;1, 2005 and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">53</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">thereafter. In addition, AWA will pay interest in kind on the aggregate
outstanding principle amount of the loan at a rate of two percent per annum
from the closing date through December&nbsp;31, 2004. In July 2002, AWA made a
mandatory repayment of approximately $16.7&nbsp;million on its $89.9&nbsp;million term
loan as a result of a decrease in the fair market value of the assets
securing the loan following the terrorist attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001.
Collateral for the loan consists of aircraft, spare engines, rotable
aircraft parts inventory and a maintenance facility. AWA and the lenders
also amended certain provisions in the loan agreement related to the
collateral appraisal procedures. The balance at December&nbsp;31, 2002 includes
$1.6&nbsp;million of interest payable in kind through December&nbsp;31, 2002.</FONT></TD>

beginning:</FONT></TD>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(c)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In January 2002, Holdings issued approximately $104.5&nbsp;million in
convertible senior notes, which are guaranteed by AWA, to certain aircraft
lessors as compensation for various elements of the restructuring plan.
The notes have a seven-year term, a coupon rate of 7.5% with interest paid
in kind for years one through three. The notes are convertible after
three years into Class&nbsp;B common stock at $12 per share. The notes may be
redeemed at the election of the Company, as a whole or in part, at any
time before January&nbsp;18, 2005, at a redemption price equal to $1,000 per
$1,000 principal amount of the notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid
interest, if any, to but excluding the date of redemption if (1)&nbsp;the
trading price of the common stock has exceeded 120% of the conversion
price then in effect for at least 20 trading days within a period of 30
consecutive trading days ending on the trading day before the date of
mailing of the notice of provisional redemption, and (2)&nbsp;a shelf
registration statement covering resales of the notes and the common stock
issuable upon conversion thereof is effective and available for use and is
expected to remain effective and available for use for the 30&nbsp;days
following the provisional redemption date, unless registration is no
longer required. At any time on or after January&nbsp;18, 2005, the Company
may, at its option, redeem the notes in whole at any time or in part from
time to time, on any date prior to the stated maturity of the notes, at
the redemption price (expressed in percentages of the principal amount)
set forth below if, but only if, redeemed on a redemption date occurring
during the 12-month period beginning on the dates indicated:</FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">For financial reporting purposes, the Company recorded the convertible

balance at December&nbsp;31, 2002 is net of an unamortized discount of $2.7
million and includes $6.2&nbsp;million of interest payable in kind through

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(d)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">The industrial development revenue bonds are due April 2023. Interest
at 6.3% is payable semiannually (April 1 and October 1). The bonds are
subject to optional redemption prior to the maturity date on or after
April&nbsp;1, 2008, in whole or in part, on any interest payment date at the
following redemption prices: 102&nbsp;percent on April 1 or October&nbsp;1, 2008;
101&nbsp;percent on April 1 or October&nbsp;1, 2009; and 100&nbsp;percent on April&nbsp;1,
2010 and thereafter.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(e)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan backed by a $380&nbsp;million
federal loan guarantee. The loan has a seven-year term with ratable
amortization in years three through seven, an interest rate of three month
LIBOR plus 40 basis points paid quarterly and guarantee fees payable to
the U.S. Treasury Department and other loan participants of 550 basis
points in year one and approximately 800 basis points thereafter. See
Note 4, <I>&#147;Government Guaranteed Loan.&#148;</I></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Secured financings totaling $132.9&nbsp;million are collateralized by assets,
primarily aircraft, engines, simulators, rotable aircraft parts and AWA&#146;s
hangar facility, with a net book value of $316.6&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">54</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain of the Company&#146;s long-term debt agreements contain minimum cash
balance requirements and other covenants with which Holdings and AWA are in
compliance. Certain of these covenants restrict the Company&#146;s ability to pay
cash dividends on its common stock and make certain other restricted payments
(as specified therein). Finally, AWA&#146;s long-term debt agreements contain
cross-default provisions, which may be triggered by defaults by AWA under other
agreements relating to indebtedness. As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, AWA had
suspended payment under certain aircraft leases and, as a result, had received
notices of default from certain aircraft lessors. In January 2002, AWA paid in
full approximately $81&nbsp;million in deferred aircraft lease payments
simultaneously with the funding of the $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380
million government loan guarantee, thereby curing the defaults. See <I>&#147;Risk
Factors Relating to America West and Industry Related Risks &#151; Our high level of
debt and fixed costs limits our ability to fund general corporate requirements,
limits our flexibility in responding to competitive developments and increases
our vulnerability to adverse economic and industry conditions.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>8. Commitments and Contingencies</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(a)&nbsp; Leases</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company had 133 aircraft under operating
leases with remaining terms ranging from three months to approximately 22
years. In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380
million government loan guarantee that resulted in a restructuring of its
aircraft lease commitments. As a result, AWA has retired 11 aircraft in 2001
and 2002 to better size its fleet to the current industry demand environment.
In addition, under the restructured lease agreements, annual rent payments have
been reduced for each of the next six years (see Note 4, <I>&#147;Government Guaranteed
Loan&#148;</I>). Certain of these leases contain put options pursuant to which the
lessors could require AWA to renew the leases for periods ranging from eight
months to 8.7&nbsp;years or call options pursuant to which the lessors could require
AWA to return the aircraft to the lessors upon receipt of four to nine months
written notice. The Company also has options to purchase certain of the
aircraft at fair market values at the end of the lease terms. Certain of the
agreements require security deposits, minimum return provisions and maintenance
reserve payments.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of the rent restructuring associated with the government
guaranteed loan, one aircraft lease was amended to include a bargain purchase
option. As a result, this lease has been classified as a capital lease in
accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;13, <I>&#147;Accounting for Leases,&#148; </I>as amended, with an asset
value of $16.9&nbsp;million and corresponding lease obligation of $14.5&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2002, one aircraft lessor exercised its put right under its
aircraft lease agreement to extend the lease for one Boeing 737-300 aircraft
for an additional 13&nbsp;months. Upon exercising this right, the lessor agreed to
relinquish its interest in approximately $0.7&nbsp;million face value of 7.5%
convertible senior notes it received as compensation for certain concessions
granted under the restructuring completed on January&nbsp;18, 2002. In October
2002, the same aircraft lessor exercised its put right to extend the lease for
another Boeing 737-300 aircraft for an additional 18&nbsp;months. Upon exercising
the right, the lessor agreed to relinquish its interest in approximately $0.9
million face value of 7.5% convertible senior notes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2002, AWA restructured the leases for six of its Boeing 757-200
aircraft to improve lease rental rates and other terms. Prior to the
restructuring, AWA subleased the six aircraft from The Boeing Company
(&#147;Boeing&#148;), who in turn leased the aircraft from five different head lessors.
Under the restructuring, AWA terminated the subleases with Boeing and assumed,
amended and restated the existing head leases for each aircraft. Upon closing
of the transactions, AWA paid approximately $11.8&nbsp;million in security deposits
and advance rental payments to the head lessors, net of a refund from Boeing
for prorated prepaid rent under the subleases, prorated accrued rent under the
head leases and cash deposits for the estimated cost of certain maintenance
work required to be performed on the aircraft prior to their return to Boeing.
As a result of these transactions, Boeing also relinquished its interest in
approximately $11.2&nbsp;million face value of 7.5% convertible notes it received as
compensation for certain
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">55</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">concessions granted under the restructuring completed on January&nbsp;18, 2002.
Furthermore, AWA issued a $4.9&nbsp;million promissory note to Boeing for the value
of the concessions realized with respect to these six aircraft prior to the
termination of the subleases, of which approximately $2.5&nbsp;million was paid in
2002. The promissory note has a fixed interest rate of 10% and matures in June
2003. The restructured leases have a remaining term of approximately six years
and are being accounted for as operating leases.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September 2002, one aircraft lessor exercised its put rights under its
aircraft lease agreements to extend the leases for two Airbus A320 aircraft for
an additional 12&nbsp;months each.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November 2002, one aircraft lessor exercised its put rights under its
aircraft lease agreements to extend the leases for four Boeing 737-300 aircraft
for an additional 18&nbsp;months each.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company also leases certain terminal space, ground facilities and
computer and other equipment under noncancelable operating leases.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rent expense (excluding landing fees) was approximately $409&nbsp;million, $457
million and $427&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000,
respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Collectively, the operating lease agreements require security deposits
with lessors of $20.9&nbsp;million and bank letters of credit of $13.8&nbsp;million. The
letters of credit are collateralized by $13.8&nbsp;million of restricted cash.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(b)&nbsp; Revenue Bonds</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 1999, Series&nbsp;1999 special facility revenue bonds (&#147;new bonds&#148;)
were issued by a municipality to fund the retirement of the Series&nbsp;1994A bonds
(&#147;old bonds&#148;) and the construction of a new concourse with 14 gates at Terminal
4 in Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport in support of AWA&#146;s strategic
growth plan. The new bonds are due June 2019 with interest accruing at 6.25%
per annum payable semiannually on June 1 and December&nbsp;1, commencing on December
1, 1999. The new bonds are subject to optional redemption prior to the
maturity date on or after June&nbsp;1, 2009 in whole or in part, on any interest
payment date at the following redemption prices: 101% on June 1 or December&nbsp;1,
2009; 100.5% on June 1 or December&nbsp;1, 2010; and 100% on June&nbsp;1, 2011 and
thereafter. In accordance with EITF Issue No.&nbsp;97-10, <I>&#147;The Effect of Lessee
Involvement in Asset Construction,&#148; </I>the Company accounts for this as an
operating lease.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
connection with these bonds, AWA entered into an Amended and Restated
Airport Use Agreement, pursuant to which AWA agreed to make
sufficient payments to the Industrial Development Authority
(&#147;IDA&#148;) to cover the principal and interest of the bonds and
to indemnify the IDA for any claims arising out of the issuance and
sale of the bonds and the use and occupancy of the concourses financed by these
bonds and the old bonds. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the outstanding
principal amount of the bonds was $21.8&nbsp;million. The Company
estimates its remaining payments to cover the principal and interest
of these bonds will be approximately $44.3&nbsp;million.</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(c)&nbsp; Aircraft Acquisitions</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2002, upon closing of the $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380
million government loan guarantee, AWA restructured its aircraft purchase
commitment to AVSA. As a result, 17 new Airbus aircraft previously scheduled
for delivery in 2003 and 2004 were deferred by a total of 505 aircraft-months
to 2004 through 2007. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, AWA had firm commitments to AVSA
for a total of 15 Airbus A318-100, one Airbus A319-100 and five Airbus A320-200
aircraft with delivery through 2007 at a cost of approximately $800&nbsp;million.
The agreement with AVSA also includes options to purchase an additional 17 A320
family aircraft during 2006 through 2008 and purchase rights for an additional
25 aircraft in the A320 family of aircraft for delivery in 2005 to 2008.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">56</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has an agreement with International Aero Engines (&#147;IAE&#148;) which
provides for the purchase by the Company of four new V2500-A5 spare engines
scheduled for delivery through 2004 for use on certain of the A320 fleet. At
December&nbsp;31, 2002, the four engines have an estimated aggregate cost of $19
million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table reflects estimated cash payments under the
restructured aircraft purchase agreement with AVSA and the IAE engine contract.
Actual payments may vary due to inflation factor adjustments and changes in
the delivery schedule of the equipment. The estimated cash payments include
progress payments that will be made in cash, as opposed to being financed under
an existing progress payment financing facility.

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May 2001, America West Airlines 2001-1 Pass Through Trusts issued
$427.2&nbsp;million of Pass Through Trust Certificates in connection with the
financing of nine Airbus A319 aircraft and five Airbus A320 aircraft. The
combined effective interest rate on this financing is 7.66% on a fixed rate
equivalent basis at the time of closing.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Pass Through Trust Certificates were issued by separate trusts that
hold equipment notes issued upon delivery of each financed aircraft. Proceeds
from the certificates were deposited in an escrow account pending their
application to purchase the equipment notes. The equipment notes were issued,
at AWA&#146;s election, either by AWA in connection with a mortgage financing of the
aircraft or by a separate owner trust in connection with a leveraged lease
financing of the aircraft. In the case of a leveraged lease financing, the
owner trust then leased the aircraft to AWA. In both cases, the equipment
notes are secured by a security interest in the aircraft. The pass through
trust certificates are not direct obligations of, nor guaranteed by, Holdings
or AWA. However, in the case of mortgage financings, the equipment notes
issued to the trusts are direct obligations of AWA and in the case of leveraged
lease financing, the leases are direct obligations of AWA.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Of the 14 aircraft financed under the 2001-1 Pass Through Trusts, 11 were
delivered in 2001, including three in the fourth quarter of 2001. One aircraft
was delivered in the first quarter of 2002 and two were delivered in the second
quarter of 2002. Except for the aircraft delivered in the first quarter of
2002, which was already financed as a leveraged lease upon delivery, the
acquisition of each aircraft was initially structured as a mortgage financing
and subsequently converted into a leveraged lease financing in sale-leaseback
transactions. In connection with the purchase of the two aircraft delivered in
the second quarter of 2002, AWA issued $64.2&nbsp;million of equipment notes. In
June 2002, AWA converted the mortgage financing of the three aircraft delivered
in the fourth quarter of 2001 and the two aircraft delivered in the second
quarter of 2002 into a leveraged lease financing by entering into
sale-leaseback transactions. As a result, approximately $161.2&nbsp;million of the
equipment notes were assumed, on a non-recourse basis, by the owner trustees
that purchased the aircraft from AWA.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2002, in conjunction with the $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a
$380&nbsp;million government loan guarantee, AWA obtained new financing commitments
for 11 aircraft which were either already delivered in 2001 or scheduled to be
delivered in 2002 and 2003. Delivery of two of these aircraft was subsequently
deferred until 2005. In order to obtain the entire amount of the financing
commitment for two of the aircraft, AWA must achieve an established minimum
liquidity threshold. As a result, AWA has financing commitments for all
scheduled aircraft deliveries through the fourth quarter of 2003. See Note 4,
<I>&#147;Government Guaranteed Loan.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(d)&nbsp; Sale-Leaseback Transactions</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As part of the restructuring completed on January&nbsp;18, 2002, AWA committed
to the sale and leaseback of eight aircraft. The sale and leaseback of five of
these aircraft was completed in June 2002 and resulted in pretax losses of
approximately $2.4&nbsp;million. The sale and leaseback of one aircraft was
completed in November 2002 and resulted in a pretax loss of approximately $1.4
million. The losses on the sale-leaseback transactions, which were subject to
a firm commitment in January 2002, were accrued in the accompanying
consolidated statements of operations classified in <I>&#147;Special Charges&#148; </I>in the
first quarter of 2002. See Note 14, <I>&#147;Special Charges.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">57</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2001, AWA borrowed $49.4&nbsp;million from the America West Airlines
2000-1 Pass Through Trusts to fund the acquisition of two new A319 Airbus
aircraft. In March 2001, AWA entered into a sale-leaseback transaction whereby
the Company sold these aircraft resulting in a $9.6&nbsp;million gain. This gain
was deferred and is being amortized over the term of the operating leases,
which approximates 22&nbsp;years, as a reduction in rent expense.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the second and third quarters of 2001, AWA borrowed $232.0&nbsp;million from
the America West Airlines 2001-1 Pass Through Trusts to fund the acquisition of
eight new A319 Airbus aircraft. In October 2001, AWA completed the sale of
these eight aircraft as part of a sale-leaseback transaction. The $34.1
million gain resulting from this transaction was deferred and is being
amortized over the term of the operating leases, which approximates 20&nbsp;years,
as a reduction in rent expense.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September 2001, AWA completed the sale of two owned aircraft engines,
with a combined net book value of $10.9&nbsp;million, for approximately $10.0
million as part of a sale-leaseback transaction. The resulting $0.9&nbsp;million
pretax loss on this transaction was recognized in the accompanying consolidated
statements of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, classified in
<I>&#147;Nonoperating Income (Expense) &#151; Other, Net.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In October 2001, AWA completed the sale of two owned A320 flight
simulators as part of a sale-leaseback transaction. The flight simulators,
with a combined net book value of $14.6&nbsp;million, were sold for approximately
$17.4&nbsp;million. The gain resulting from this transaction was deferred and is
being amortized over the term of the operating lease, which approximates nine
years, as a reduction in rent expense.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(e)&nbsp; Contingent Legal Obligations</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holdings and its subsidiaries are parties to various legal proceedings,
including some purporting to be class action suits, and some which demand large
monetary damages or other relief, which, if granted, would require significant
expenditures. In certain cases where it is probable that the outcome will
result in monetary damages, the Company has reviewed available information and
determined that the best estimate of losses to be incurred related to these
cases is $2&nbsp;million, which has been accrued. For those cases where a loss is
possible, or cases where a range of loss is probable but no amount within the
range is a better estimate than any other amount, the estimated amount of
exposure ranges from $0 to $25&nbsp;million. In these instances, no accrual has
been recorded.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(f)&nbsp; General Guarantees and Indemnifications</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is the lessee under many aircraft financing agreements
(including leveraged lease financings of aircraft under the pass through
trusts) and real estate leases. It is common in such transactions for the
Company as the lessee to agree to indemnify the lessor and other related third
parties for the manufacture, design, ownership, financing, use, operation and
maintenance of the aircraft, and for tort liabilities that arise out of or
relate to the Company&#146;s use or occupancy of the leased asset. In some cases,
this indemnity extends to related liabilities arising from the negligence of
the indemnified parties, but usually excludes any liabilities caused by their
gross negligence or willful misconduct. Additionally, in the case of real
estate leases, the Company typically indemnifies such parties for any
environmental liability that arises out of or relates to the Company&#146;s use of
the leased premises. The Company expects that it would be covered by insurance
(subject to deductibles) for most tort liabilities and related indemnities
described above with respect to leased real estate and operated aircraft.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>9. Income Taxes</B>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s emergence from bankruptcy reorganization in 1994 and the
associated implementation of fresh start reporting gave rise to significant
items of expense for financial reporting purposes that are not deductible for
income tax purposes. In large measure, it is these nondeductible (for income
tax purposes) expenses that result in an effective tax expense (benefit)&nbsp;rate
for financial reporting purposes that differs from the current federal
statutory income tax rate of 35% for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 and
2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income tax expense (benefit)&nbsp;differs from amounts computed at the federal
statutory income tax rate as follows:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="85%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="56%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
