</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company has available net operating loss
carryforwards (&#147;NOL&#148;), business tax credit carryforwards and alternative
minimum tax credit carryforwards for federal income tax purposes of
approximately $399.6&nbsp;million, $1.9&nbsp;million, $1.2&nbsp;million, respectively. The
NOL expire during the years 2007 through 2009 while the business credit
carryforwards expire during the years 2003 through 2006. However, such
carryforwards are not available to offset federal (and in certain
circumstances, state) alternative minimum taxable income. Further, as a result
of a statutory &#147;ownership change&#148; (as defined for purposes of Section&nbsp;382 of
the Internal Revenue Code) that occurred as a result of the Company&#146;s
reorganization in 1994, the Company&#146;s ability to utilize its NOL and business
tax credit carryforwards may be restricted. The alternative minimum tax credit
may be carried forward without expiration and is available to offset future
income tax payable to the extent regular income tax exceeds alternative minimum
tax in any given year.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February 2002, Holdings filed its 2001 consolidated income tax return
with the IRS, which included a claim to carryback losses incurred in 2001 to
the tax years 1999 and 2000. This resulted in a refund of approximately $33.9
million, of which substantially all was received in the first quarter of 2002.
In March 2002, Holdings filed a revised claim for carryback losses under the
Job Creation and Workers Assistance Act of 2002, resulting in an additional
refund of approximately $26.4&nbsp;million which was received in the second quarter
of 2002. Holdings will be able to carryback a portion of its 2002 loss to
prior years and obtain a refund of $3.2&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Composition of Deferred Tax Items</I></B>:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred income taxes reflect the net tax effects of temporary differences
between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting
purposes and the amounts used for income tax purposes. As of December&nbsp;31, the
significant components of the Company&#146;s deferred tax assets and liabilities are
a result of the temporary differences related to the items described as
follows:
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">59</FONT>

</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="3"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">112,213</FONT></TD>

    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">95,664</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="3"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Net deferred tax asset (liability)</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">&#151;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">&#151;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="3"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS No.&nbsp;109, <I>&#147;Accounting for Income Taxes,&#148; </I>requires that a valuation
allowance be established when it is &#147;more likely than not&#148; that all or a
portion of deferred tax assets will not be realized. A review of all available
positive and negative evidence needs to be considered, including the company&#146;s
performance, the market environment in which the company operates, forecasts of
future profitability, the utilization of past tax credits, length of
carryforward periods and similar factors. SFAS No.&nbsp;109 further states that it
is difficult to conclude that a valuation allowance is not needed when there is
negative evidence such as cumulative losses in recent years. Therefore,
cumulative losses weigh heavily in the overall assessment.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company was in a cumulative loss position for the three years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001. Accordingly, a full valuation allowance has been
established relating to the Company&#146;s net deferred tax assets as December&nbsp;31,
2001, and to tax benefits generated in 2002. We expect to continue to record a
full valuation allowance on future tax benefits until we can sustain an
appropriate level of profitability.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>10. Capital Stock</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Preferred Stock</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s Board of Directors by resolution may authorize the issuance
of the preferred stock as a class, in one or more series, having the number of
shares, designations, relative voting rights, dividend rights, liquidation and
other preferences and limitations that the Board of Directors fixes, without
any stockholder approval. No shares of preferred stock have been issued.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Common Stock</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The holders of Class&nbsp;A common stock are entitled to fifty votes per share,
and the holders of Class&nbsp;B common stock are entitled to one vote per share, on
all matters submitted to a vote of common stockholders except that voting
rights of non-U.S. citizens are limited. The Class&nbsp;A common stock is
convertible into an equal number of Class&nbsp;B shares at any time at the election
of the holders of the Class&nbsp;A common stock. Holdings&#146; Class&nbsp;B common stock is
listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holders of common stock of all classes participate equally as to any
dividends or distributions on the common stock, except that dividends payable
in shares of common stock, or securities to acquire common stock, will be made
in the same class of common stock as that held by the recipient of the
dividend. Holders of common stock have no right to cumulate their votes in the
election of directors. The common stock votes together as a single class,
subject to the right to a separate class vote in certain instances required by
law.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Treasury Stock</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September 1995, the Company adopted a stock repurchase program. The
program was amended in December 1995, August 1997, August 1998, May 1999 and
February 2000. During 1995 through 2000, the Company repurchased approximately
16.5&nbsp;million shares of Class&nbsp;B common stock and 7.4&nbsp;million warrants. The
Company did not repurchase any Class&nbsp;B common stock in 2001 or 2002 and the
stock repurchase program expired on December&nbsp;31, 2002. Under the terms of the
government guaranteed loan (see Note 4, <I>&#147;Government Guaranteed Loan&#148;</I>), the
Company is prohibited from purchasing any additional shares of its stock prior
to repayment of the loan
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">60</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;in full.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Warrants</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As compensation for various elements of the Company&#146;s financial
restructuring completed in January 2002, Holdings issued a warrant to purchase
18.8&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;B common stock to the federal government and
additional warrants to purchase 3.8&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;B common stock
to other loan participants, in each case at an exercise price of $3 per share
and a term of ten years. For accounting purposes, the warrants were valued at
$35.4&nbsp;million, or $1.57 per share, using the Black-Scholes pricing model with
the following assumptions: expected dividend yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest
rate of 4.8%, volatility of 44.9% and an expected life of ten years.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>11. Stock Options and Awards</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the 1994 Incentive Equity Plan, as amended (the &#147;1994 Incentive
Plan&#148;), the Company&#146;s Board of Directors (the &#147;Board&#148;) was authorized to grant
stock options to officers and key employees. The maximum number of shares of
Class&nbsp;B common stock authorized for issuance under the Plan was 9.0&nbsp;million
shares.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of March&nbsp;27, 2002, only 205,831 shares of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;B common
stock remained available for future grants under the 1994 Incentive Plan. As
of that date, although awards covering an aggregate of 6,799,570 shares of
Class&nbsp;B common stock remained outstanding under the 1994 Incentive Plan, all
options granted prior to December&nbsp;31, 2001 were significantly out-of-the-money
(based on the $5.55 per share closing price of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;B common
stock as reported on the New York Stock Exchange on March&nbsp;27, 2002) due to the
significant drop in the price of the Company&#146;s stock during 2001 (largely as a
result of the events of September&nbsp;11, 2001 and its aftermath). Consequently,
these options had lost substantially all value as retention and incentive
tools. The Board is strongly opposed to repricing outstanding stock options
and, in connection with the government guaranteed loan, the Company agreed not
to reprice any outstanding stock options so long as the loan remains
outstanding.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For these reasons, on March&nbsp;27, 2002, the Board adopted the Company&#146;s 2002
Incentive Equity Plan (the &#147;2002 Incentive Plan&#148;), subject to stockholder
approval. A total of 8,000,000 shares of Class&nbsp;B common stock, which the
Company believes will be adequate to fund the requirements under its long-term
compensation arrangements through 2005, have been reserved for issuance under
the 2002 Incentive Plan. At the same time, the Board determined that,
regardless of share availability, no new awards will be granted under the 1994
Incentive Plan following stockholder approval of the 2002 Incentive Plan. In
May 2002, the Company&#146;s stockholders approved the adoption of the 2002
Incentive Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock options are granted with an exercise price equal to the stock&#146;s fair
market value at the date of grant, generally become exercisable over a
three-year period and expire if unexercised at the end of 10&nbsp;years. At
December&nbsp;31, 2002, approximately 6.0&nbsp;million shares are available for grant
under the 2002 Incentive Plan.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock option activity during the years indicated is as follows:

</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There were 4,027,196 and 3,205,576 stock options exercisable as of
December&nbsp;31, 2001 and December&nbsp;31, 2000, respectively. The per share
weighted-average fair value of stock options granted during 2002, 2001 and 2000
was $2.87, $3.92 and $5.38, respectively, on the date of grant using the
Black-Scholes option pricing model with the following weighted-average
assumptions: 2002 &#151; expected dividend yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest rate of
3.9%, volatility of 87.9% and an expected life of four years; 2001 &#151; expected
dividend yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest rate of 4.8%, volatility of 44.9%
and an expected life of four years; 2000 &#151; expected dividend yield of 0.0%,
risk-free interest rate of 6.1%, volatility of 52.2% and an expected life of
four years.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the 1994 Plan, the Company granted 20,000 shares of Class&nbsp;B common
stock as restricted stock to certain officers and key employees in 2000. There
were no restricted stock grants in 2001 or 2002. The Company recognized
compensation expense of $0.7&nbsp;million, $0.8&nbsp;million and $1.6&nbsp;million related to
restricted stock in 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. At December&nbsp;31, 2002,
78,462 shares of restricted stock were vested.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The stock option plans also provide for the issuance of stock and grant of
stock options to non-employee directors. The Company has granted options to
purchase 363,000 shares of Class&nbsp;B common stock to members of the Board of
Directors who are not employees of the Company. The options have a ten-year
term and are exercisable six months after the date of grant. As of December
31, 2002, 249,000 options were outstanding and exercisable at prices ranging
from $3.20 to $29.19 per share. On December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000, non-employee
directors were also granted Class&nbsp;B common stock pursuant to the 1994 Plan
totaling 9,750 shares and 9,000 shares, respectively. There were no grants of
Class&nbsp;B common stock to non-employee directors in 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>12. Other Comprehensive Income (Loss)</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other comprehensive income (loss)&nbsp;includes unrealized gains and losses on
available-for-sale securities and changes in the fair value of derivative
financial instruments that qualify for hedge accounting. For the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, the Company recorded a total comprehensive loss of
$387.3&nbsp;million and $247.4&nbsp;million, respectively. The difference between net
income (loss)&nbsp;and comprehensive loss for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and
2001 is detailed in the following table:
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">62</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="90%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July 2000, Holdings completed the sale of America West Golf Vacations,
a division of TLC, to Book4golf.com, a provider of Internet-based, real-time,
golf tee time reservation systems. TLC received 900,000 common shares, with a
fair market value of $2.1&nbsp;million. The Company recorded a nonoperating pretax
gain on sale of $2.0&nbsp;million in the third quarter of 2000. In accordance with
SFAS No.&nbsp;115, <I>&#147;Accounting for Certain Investments in Debt and Equity
Securities,&#148; </I>the Company had classified TLC&#146;s investment in Book4golf.com as
available-for-sale securities in the Company&#146;s consolidated balance sheet.
SFAS No.&nbsp;130, <I>&#147;Reporting Comprehensive Income&#148; </I>requires unrealized gains or
losses on the Company&#146;s available-for-sale securities to be included in
accumulated other comprehensive income, a component of stockholders&#146; equity.
In the third quarter of 2001, management determined the decline in market value
of the Company&#146;s investment in Book4golf.com, approximately $2.1&nbsp;million since
July 2000, was other than temporary. In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;12,
<I>&#147;Accounting for Certain Marketable Securities,&#148; </I>the investment was written down
to realizable value, recognizing a nonoperating pretax loss of $2.1&nbsp;million.
The tax benefit associated with the loss was $0.8&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>13. Employee Benefit Plan</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has a 401(k) defined contribution plan, covering essentially
all employees of the Company. Participants may contribute from 1 to 15% of
their pretax earnings to a maximum of $11,000 in 2002. The Company&#146;s matching
contribution is determined annually by the Board of Directors. The Company&#146;s
contribution expense to the plan totaled $8.7&nbsp;million, $8.1&nbsp;million and $9.0
million in 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>14. Special Charges</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the first quarter of 2002, the Company recorded a pretax special charge
of $21.1&nbsp;million, primarily related to the restructuring completed on January
18, 2002, resulting from the events of September&nbsp;11, 2001. Components of the
special charge are as follows:
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Of this amount, approximately $10.3&nbsp;million, principally related to losses
on sale-leaseback transactions, fleet restructuring costs, professional fees
and severance was accrued.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter of 2002, the Company recorded a $2.0&nbsp;million
reduction in special charges due to a revision of the estimated costs related
to the early termination of certain aircraft leases.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">63</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April 2001, Holdings implemented a cost reduction plan to respond to a
softening economy. The plan included a slowing of the airline&#146;s growth through
the return of seven older 737-300 leased aircraft to the lessors in the second
half of 2001 and January 2002 and significant reductions in overhead due in
part to select reductions-in-force of management, administrative and clerical
personnel. The Company recorded a pretax charge of $35.7&nbsp;million in the second
quarter of 2001 related to the earlier-than-planned aircraft returns and
reductions-in-force.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the fourth quarter of 2001, the Company recorded a pretax special
charge of $106.0&nbsp;million related to the impairment of owned aircraft
and engines as a result of declines in market value resulting from
the terrorist attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001 and their aftermath.
Fair value for purposes of determining impairment was determined by
independent appraisal and the impairment charge included an
allocation of unamortized ERV at December&nbsp;31, 2001 of
approximately $64.1&nbsp;million. Special charges for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001 also include charges for the early termination of leases for one A320 and one 737-300
aircraft.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table presents the payments and other settlements made
during 2002 and the remaining special charge accruals as of December&nbsp;31, 2002.
</FONT>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(a)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">As restated &#151; See Note 2</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company expects to make payments related to these special charges
through the fourth quarter of 2005.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Nonoperating Income (Expense) &#151; Other, Net</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the airline compensation provisions of the Air Transportation Safety
and System Stabilization Act (the &#147;Act&#148;), each air carrier was entitled to
receive the lesser of: (i)&nbsp;its direct and incremental losses for the period
September&nbsp;11, 2001 to December&nbsp;31, 2001 or (ii)&nbsp;its proportional available seat
mile allocation (based on available seat miles for August 2001) of the $4.5
billion compensation available under the Act. In 2001, AWA received $98.2
million under the Act from the United States government and expected to
receive, based on its losses and its share of available seat miles, at least an
additional $10.0&nbsp;million. In accordance with EITF Issue No.&nbsp;01-10, <I>&#147;Accounting
for the Impact of the Terrorist Attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001,&#148; </I>AWA recognized
$108.2&nbsp;million of federal government assistance in 2001 as nonoperating income
because direct and incremental losses incurred during 2001 exceeded that
amount. In July 2002, AWA received an additional $12.3&nbsp;million under the Act.
Accordingly, $10.0&nbsp;million was credited against the receivable established in
2001 and $2.3&nbsp;million was recognized as nonoperating income in the second
quarter of 2002. In August 2002, AWA received an additional payment of $6.2
million under the Act, which was recognized as nonoperating income in the third
quarter of 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March 2002, the Company wrote down its investment in Aeroxchange, an
e-commerce entity, which was carried at cost, to net realizable value
recognizing a pretax loss of $2.8&nbsp;million. See Note 6, <I>&#147;Financial Instruments
and Risk Management &#151; (a)&nbsp;Fair Value of Financial Instruments &#151; Investments in
Equity Securities.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September 2001, AWA completed the sale of two owned aircraft engines,
with a combined net book value of $10.9&nbsp;million, for approximately $10.0
million as part of a sale leaseback transaction, resulting in a $0.9&nbsp;million
pretax loss.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July 2001, AWA recognized a pretax gain of approximately $1.1&nbsp;million
from the sale of 62,240 warrants to purchase common stock of Expedia.com.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">64</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September 2000, AWA recorded an $8.8&nbsp;million pretax unrealized gain on
the Company&#146;s investment in one million shares of GetThere.com common stock.
AWA sold all one million shares of GetThere.com for approximately $17.8&nbsp;million
in October 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July 2000, Holdings completed the sale of America West Golf Vacations,
a division of TLC, to Book4golf.com, a provider of Internet-based, real-time,
golf tee time reservation systems. TLC received 900,000 common shares, with a
fair market value of $2.1&nbsp;million. The Company recorded a nonoperating pretax
gain on sale of $2.0&nbsp;million in the third quarter of 2000. In the third
quarter of 2001, management determined the decline in market value of the
Company&#146;s investment in Book4golf.com, approximately $2.1&nbsp;million since July
2000, was other than temporary. In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;12, <I>&#147;Accounting
for Certain Marketable Securities,&#148; </I>the investment was written down to
realizable value, recognizing a pretax loss of $2.1&nbsp;million. See
Note 12, <I>&#147;Other Comprehensive Income (Loss).&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May 2000, Holdings completed the sale of a majority interest in TLC&#146;s
retail operations, National Leisure Group and The Vacation Store, to Softbank
Capital Partners and General Catalyst LLC. TLC received $52&nbsp;million in cash
and retained a 12% passive ownership interest in the restructured venture. The
Company recorded a $9.2&nbsp;million pretax gain on this sale transaction.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March 2000, AWA sold 500,000 warrants to purchase common stock of
Priceline.com, Inc. for approximately $18.0&nbsp;million, resulting in a pretax gain
of approximately $15.5&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000, options of
7,292,706, 5,062,194 and 3,592,311 respectively, are not included in the
computation of diluted EPS because the option exercise prices were greater than
the average market price of common stock for the period. In addition, for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 22,074 incremental shares from assumed exercise
of stock options and 2,794,399 incremental shares from assumed exercise of
warrants issued in conjunction with the government guaranteed loan are not
included in the computation of diluted EPS because of the antidilutive effect
on EPS. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, 68,677 incremental shares from
assumed exercise of stock options are not included in the computation of
diluted EPS
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">65</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>18. Related Party Transactions</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As part of our reorganization in 1994, Continental Airlines and AWA
entered into an alliance agreement which included code sharing arrangements,
reciprocal frequent flyer programs and ground handling operations. In March
2002, AWA received notice from Continental of its intention to terminate the
code sharing and frequent flyer agreements between the two airlines, effective
April&nbsp;26, 2002. Two of Continental&#146;s directors are managing partners of Texas
Pacific Group, which, through TPG Advisors, Inc., effectively controls the
voting power of Holdings. See <I>&#147;Risk Factors Relating to America West and
Industry Related Risks &#151; The stockholders who effectively control the voting
power of Holdings could take actions that would favor their own personal
interests to the detriment of our interests.&#148; </I>AWA paid Continental
approximately $25.5&nbsp;million, $30.1&nbsp;million and $32.4&nbsp;million and also received
approximately $15.9&nbsp;million, $22.0&nbsp;million and $25.5&nbsp;million in 2002, 2001 and
2000, respectively, from Continental pursuant to these agreements.
</FONT>

    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">(0.25</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap><FONT size="2">)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#150; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>20.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment Disclosures</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holdings is one reportable operating segment. Accordingly, the segment
reporting financial data required by SFAS No.&nbsp;131 is included in the
accompanying consolidated balance sheets and statements of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>21.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent Event</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Elimination of Hub Operations in Columbus, Ohio</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February 2003, AWA announced that it is eliminating hub operations in
Columbus, Ohio and, as a result, will be phasing 12 regional jets out of the
America West Express fleet. Between early April and mid-June of 2003, AWA will
gradually downsize the hub from 49 daily departures to 15 destinations to a
planned four mainline flights per day to Phoenix and Las Vegas. With the
downsizing of Columbus, AWA must eliminate service to New York City LaGuardia
Airport because perimeter rules at the airport prohibit flights beyond 1,500
miles. This precludes service from AWA&#146;s hubs in Phoenix and Las Vegas. In
the first, second and thirds quarters of 2003, the Company expects to record a
pre-tax special charge of approximately $10 to $15&nbsp;million resulting from the
elimination of its Columbus hub operations. The charge is related to the costs
to terminate certain contracts, the write-off of leasehold improvements and
employee transfer and severance expenses.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">68</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left"><A NAME="011"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>ITEM 8B. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTARY DATA &#151; AMERICA WEST AIRLINES,
INC. (&#147;AWA&#148;)</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Balance sheets of AWA as of December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, and the related
statements of operations, of cash flows and of stockholder&#146;s equity and
comprehensive income for each of the years in the three-year period ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002, together with the related notes and the reports of
PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, independent accountants, and KPMG LLP, independent
auditors, are set forth on the following pages.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">69</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTANTS</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>The Board of Directors and Stockholder<BR>
of America West Airlines, Inc.:</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In our opinion, the accompanying balance sheets and the related statements
of operations, of cash flows and of stockholder&#146;s equity and comprehensive
income (loss)&nbsp;present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position
of America West Airlines, Inc. (a wholly owned subsidiary of America West
Holdings Corporation) at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, and the results of its
operations and its cash flows for the years then ended in conformity with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company&#146;s management;
our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based
on our audits. We conducted our audits of these statements in accordance with
auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America, which
require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about
whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit
includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and
disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles
used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall
financial statement presentation. We believe that our audits provide a
reasonable basis for our opinion.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As more
fully described in Note 2, the Company has restated its financial
statements for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 to reflect impairment
charges on long-lived assets.</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Note&nbsp;3 to the financial
statements, the Company changed its method of accounting for reorganization
value in excess of amounts allocable to identifiable assets in connection with
the adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;142, &#147;Goodwill
and Other Intangible Assets&#148; effective January&nbsp;1, 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP<BR>
Phoenix, Arizona<BR>
March&nbsp;24, 2003</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">70</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>INDEPENDENT AUDITORS&#146; REPORT</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>The Board of Directors and Stockholder<BR>
America West Airlines, Inc.:</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have audited the accompanying statements of operations, cash flows and
stockholder&#146;s equity of America West Airlines, Inc. for the year ended December
31, 2000. These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company&#146;s
management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial
statements based on our audit.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We conducted our audit in accordance with auditing standards generally
accepted in the United States of America. Those standards require that we plan
and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the
financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes
examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in
the financial statements. An audit also includes assessing the accounting

principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as
evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. We believe that our
audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly,
in all material respects, the results of operations and cash flows of America
West Airlines, Inc. for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000, in conformity with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">KPMG LLP<BR>
Phoenix, Arizona<BR>
March&nbsp;28, 2001
</FONT>

    <TD><FONT size="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
Statements of Stockholder&#146;s Equity and Comprehensive Income<BR>
For the Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000<BR>
(in thousands except share data)</B>

</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">75</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST HOLDINGS CORPORATION<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<BR>
DECEMBER 31, 2002, 2001 AND 2000</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;America West Holdings Corporation (&#147;Holdings&#148; or the &#147;Company) is a
holding company that owns all of the stock of America West Airlines, Inc.
(&#147;AWA&#148; or the &#147;Airline&#148;). AWA accounted for most of the Company&#146;s revenues and
expenses in 2002. Based on 2002 revenues and operations, AWA is the eighth
largest passenger airline in the United States with the lowest cost structure
of the eight major hub-and-spoke airlines. At the end of 2002, AWA operated a
fleet of 143 aircraft with an average fleet age of 10.1&nbsp;years and served 65
destinations in North America, including seven in Mexico and three in Canada.
Through regional alliance and code share arrangements with other airlines, AWA
served an additional 49 destinations in North America as of December&nbsp;31, 2002.
In 2002, AWA flew approximately 19.5&nbsp;million passengers and generated revenues
of approximately $2&nbsp;billion.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since September&nbsp;11, 2001, the U.S. domestic airline industry has
experienced an unprecedented financial crisis caused by the combination of the
terrorist attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001 and soft economic conditions. In
response to these difficult industry conditions, AWA completed a financial
restructuring, introduced a business-friendly pricing structure and lowered its
cost structure in 2002. Despite these measures, AWA expects to continue to
post significant losses in 2003. AWA believes near-term revenues will continue
to be negatively impacted by the soft economic conditions and the decline in
business traffic. In addition, fuel prices have remained and may continue to
remain well above historical norms due to the threat of and the commencement of
military action against Iraq and continued political tension in Venezuela.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA expects to fund its obligations from funds provided by operations, the
proceeds of the government guaranteed loan, the financing commitments for
Airbus aircraft obtained in connection with the government loan, and future
financings, if necessary. The cash available to AWA from these sources,
however, may not be sufficient to cover these cash obligations because economic
factors outside AWA&#146;s control may reduce the amount of cash generated by
operations or increase its costs. As noted above, if AWA fails to generate
sufficient cash from operations and other sources, it may need to obtain
additional financings to achieve its longer term business objectives. There
can be no assurance that such financings will be available or, if available,
will be at rates or prices acceptable to AWA.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although there can be no assurances, management believes that cash flow
from operating activities coupled with existing cash balances and financing
commitments will be adequate to fund AWA&#146;s operating and capital needs as well
as enable it to maintain compliance with its various debt agreements through at
least December&nbsp;31, 2003.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(a)&nbsp; Cash, Cash Equivalents and Short-term Investments</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash equivalents consist of all highly liquid debt instruments purchased
with original maturities of three months or less. Short-term investments
consist of cash invested in certain debt securities with original maturities
greater than 90&nbsp;days and less than one year. The debt securities are
classified as held to maturity and are carried at amortized cost which
approximates fair value.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(b)&nbsp; Expendable Spare Parts and Supplies</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Flight equipment expendable spare parts and supplies are valued at average
cost. An allowance for obsolescence is provided, over the estimated useful
life of the related aircraft and engines, for spare parts expected to be on
hand at the date the aircraft are retired from service. In the fourth quarter
of 2000, AWA committed to the disposal of certain excess expendable spare parts
inventory with a net book value of approximately $11.0&nbsp;million. As a result,
AWA recorded an operating expense of $9.0&nbsp;million to write down excess
inventory to net realizable value.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(c)&nbsp; Property and Equipment</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property and equipment are recorded at cost. Interest capitalized on
advance payments for aircraft acquisitions and on expenditures for aircraft
improvements are part of these costs. Interest capitalized for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000 was $3.0&nbsp;million, $12.5&nbsp;million and $9.0
million, respectively. Property and equipment is depreciated and amortized to
residual values over the estimated useful lives or the lease term, whichever is
less, using the straight-line method.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">76</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS-CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The estimated useful lives for AWA&#146;s ground property and equipment range
from three to 12&nbsp;years for owned property and equipment and up to 22&nbsp;years for
the technical support facility. The estimated useful lives of AWA&#146;s owned
aircraft, jet engines, flight equipment and rotable parts range from five to 30
years. Leasehold improvements relating to flight equipment and other property on operating leases are
amortized over the life of the lease or the life of the asset, whichever is
shorter.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA records impairment losses on long-lived assets used in operations when
events and circumstances indicate that the assets might be impaired as defined
by SFAS No.&nbsp;144, <I>&#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived
Assets.&#148; </I>Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a
comparison of the carrying amount of an asset to undiscounted future net cash
flows expected to be generated by the asset. If such assets are considered to
be impaired, the impairment to be recognized is measured by the amount by which
the carrying amount of the assets exceeds the fair value of the assets. Assets
to be disposed of are reported at the lower of the carrying amount or fair
value less cost to sell.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(d)&nbsp; Restricted Cash</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restricted cash includes cash deposits securing certain letters of credit
and surety bonds and cash held by institutions that process credit card sales
transactions.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(e)&nbsp; Aircraft Maintenance and Repairs</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Routine maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred. The
cost of major scheduled airframe, engine and certain component overhauls are
capitalized and amortized over the periods benefited and are included in
aircraft maintenance materials and repairs expense. Additionally, an accrual
for the estimated cost of scheduled airframe and engine overhauls required to
be performed on leased aircraft prior to their return to the lessors has been
recorded.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(f)&nbsp; Reorganization Value in Excess of Amounts Allocable to Identifiable
Assets (&#147;ERV&#148;)</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2001, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;142, <I>&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible
Assets.&#148; </I>SFAS No.&nbsp;142 primarily addresses the accounting for goodwill and
intangible assets subsequent to their acquisition. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 does not
permit the amortization of goodwill as required by APB Opinion No.&nbsp;17,
<I>&#147;Intangible Assets.&#148; </I>Rather, goodwill is subject to a periodic impairment
test, using a two-step process. The first step is to identify a potential
impairment. The second step of the goodwill impairment test measures the
amount of the impairment loss, using a fair value-based approach. Under SFAS
No.&nbsp;142, ERV is reported as goodwill and accounted for in the same manner as
goodwill. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 was effective for fiscal years beginning after December
15, 2001. Upon adoption of this statement on January&nbsp;1, 2002, AWA recorded an
impairment loss of $187.9&nbsp;million, which was supported by an independent
valuation of the Company. The impairment loss was recorded as the cumulative
effect of a change in accounting principle. See Note 3, <I>&#147;Adoption of New
Accounting Standard.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142, ERV was amortized on a straight line
basis over 20&nbsp;years. Accumulated amortization at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000
was $171.7&nbsp;million and $151.8&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(g)&nbsp; Derivative Instruments</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA&#146;s fuel hedging contracts qualify as cash flow hedges under SFAS No.
133, <I>&#147;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities,&#148; </I>as they
hedge exposure to variable cash flows of forecasted transactions. Accordingly,
the derivative hedging instrument is recorded as an asset or liability on the
balance sheet at fair value and the effective portion of changes in the fair
value are initially recorded in <I>&#147;Other Comprehensive Income (Loss)&#148; </I>until the
underlying fuel being hedged is used. The ineffective portion of changes in
fair value are recorded in earnings.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(h)&nbsp; Frequent Flyer Awards</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA maintains a frequent travel award program known as &#147;FlightFund&#148; that
provides a variety of awards to program members based on accumulated mileage.
The estimated cost of providing the free travel, using the incremental cost
method as adjusted for estimated redemption rates, is recognized as a liability
and charged to operations as program members accumulate mileage.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">77</FONT>



<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA also sells mileage credits to companies participating in its
FlightFund program, such as hotels, car rental agencies and credit card
companies. Revenue from the sale of mileage credits is deferred and recognized
when transportation is provided.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(i)&nbsp; Deferred Credit-Operating Leases</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rents for operating leases were adjusted to fair market value when AWA
emerged from bankruptcy in 1994. The net present value of the difference
between the stated lease rates and the fair market rates has been recorded as a
deferred credit in the accompanying balance sheets. The deferred credit will
be increased through charges to interest expense and decreased on a
straight-line basis as a reduction in rent expense over the applicable lease
periods. At December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, the unamortized balance of the
deferred credit was $52.4&nbsp;million and $58.7&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380
million government loan guarantee. See Note 4, <I>&#147;Government Guaranteed Loan.&#148;</I>
This loan triggered aircraft rent concessions negotiated with approximately 20
aircraft lessors. Approximately $18.1&nbsp;million of aircraft rent, which was
accrued as of December&nbsp;31, 2001, was waived by the aircraft lessors. This
amount has been recorded as a deferred credit in the accompanying balance sheet
at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and will be amortized over the remaining lives of the
applicable leases as a reduction in rent expense. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the
unamortized balance of the deferred credit was approximately $10.9&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(j)&nbsp; Passenger Revenue</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Passenger revenue is recognized when transportation is provided. Ticket
sales for transportation which has not yet been provided are recorded as air
traffic liability. Passenger traffic commissions and related fees are expensed
when the related revenue is recognized. Passenger traffic commissions and
related fees not yet recognized are included as a prepaid expense. Passenger
traffic commissions and related fees not yet recognized are included as a
prepaid expense. Due to complex pricing structures, refund and exchange
policies, and interline agreements with other airlines, certain amounts are
recognized in revenue using estimates regarding both the timing of the revenue
recognition and the amount of revenue to be recognized. These estimates are
generally based on the statistical analysis of the Company&#146;s historical data.
Any adjustments resulting from periodic evaluations of the estimated air
traffic liability are included in results of operations during the period in
which the evaluations are completed.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(k)&nbsp; Advertising Costs</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA expenses the costs of advertising as incurred. Advertising expense
for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000 was $6.5&nbsp;million, $10.1
million and $18.7&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(l)&nbsp; Income Taxes</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability method.
Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax
consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement
carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax
bases and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards. A valuation
allowance is established, if necessary, for the amount of any tax
benefits that, based on available evidence, are not expected to be
realized.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(m)&nbsp; New Accounting Standards</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;145, &#147;<I>Rescission of FASB
Statements No.&nbsp;4, 44, and 64, Amendment of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;13, and Technical
Corrections as of April 2002</I>.&#148; This standard rescinds SFAS No.&nbsp;4, &#147;<I>Reporting
Gains and Losses from Extinguishment of Debt</I>,&#148; and an amendment of that
Statement, SFAS No.&nbsp;64, &#147;<I>Extinguishments of Debt Made to Satisfy Sinking-Fund
Requirements</I>&#148; and excludes extraordinary item treatment for gains and losses
associated with the extinguishment of debt that do not meet the APB Opinion No.
30, &#147;<I>Reporting the Results of Operations &#151; Reporting the Effects of Disposal
of a Segment of a Business, and Extraordinary, Unusual and Infrequently
Occurring Events and Transactions</I>&#148; criteria. Any gain or loss on
extinguishment of debt that was classified as an extraordinary item in prior
periods presented that does not meet the criteria in APB No.&nbsp;30 for
classification as an extraordinary item shall be reclassified. SFAS No.&nbsp;145
also amends SFAS No.&nbsp;13, <I>&#147;Accounting for Leases,</I>&#148; as well as other existing
authoritative pronouncements to make various technical corrections, clarify
meanings, or describe their applicability under changed conditions. AWA
adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;145 effective January&nbsp;1, 2002 with no material impact on its
financial condition or results of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">78</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;146, <I>&#147;Accounting for Costs
Associated with Exit or Disposal Activities.&#148; </I>This standard addresses
financial accounting and reporting for costs associated with exit or disposal
activities and replaces EITF Issue No.&nbsp;94-3, <I>&#147;Liability Recognition for Certain
Employee Termination Benefits and Other Costs to Exit an Activity (including
Certain Costs Incurred in a Restructuring.</I>)<I>&#148; </I>SFAS No.&nbsp;146 requires that a
liability for costs associated with an exit or disposal activity be recognized
when the liability is incurred. Under EITF No.&nbsp;94-3, a liability for exit
costs, as defined in EITF No.&nbsp;94-3, was recognized at the date of an entity&#146;s
commitment to an exit plan. The provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;146 are effective for
exit or disposal activities that are initiated by AWA after December&nbsp;31, 2002.
In February 2003, AWA announced that it will eliminate hub operations in
Columbus, Ohio. In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;146, AWA expects to record pretax
special charges of approximately $10 to $15&nbsp;million. See Note 20, <I>&#147;Subsequent
Event &#150; Elimination of Hub Operations in Columbus, Ohio.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November 2002, the FASB issued Interpretation (&#147;FIN&#148;) No.&nbsp;45,
<I>&#147;Guarantor&#146;s Accounting and Disclosure Requirements for Guarantees, Including
Indirect Guarantees of Indebtedness of Others.&#148; </I>FIN No.&nbsp;45 requires a
guarantor to recognize, at the inception of a guarantee, a liability for the
fair value of the obligation undertaken in issuing the guarantee. FIN No.&nbsp;45
also expands the disclosures required to be made by a guarantor about its
obligations under certain guarantees that it has issued. Initial recognition
and measurement provisions of FIN No.&nbsp;45 are applicable on a prospective basis
to guarantees issued or modified. The disclosure requirements are effective
immediately. While the Company has various indemnity obligations included in
contracts entered into in the normal course of business, these obligations are
primarily in the form of indemnities that could result in immaterial increases
of future costs, but do not represent significant commitments or contingent
liabilities of the indebtedness of others. As a result, the Company does not
expect FIN 45 to have a material effect on its financial condition or results
of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December 2002, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;148, <I>&#147;Accounting for
Stock-Based Compensation &#151; Transition and Disclosure, an amendment of SFAS No.
123.&#148; </I>SFAS No.&nbsp;148 amended SFAS No.&nbsp;123, <I>&#147;Accounting for Stock-Based
Compensation,&#148; </I>to provide alternative methods of transition for an entity that
voluntarily changes to the fair value based method of accounting for
stock-based employee compensation. It also amends the disclosure provisions of
SFAS No.&nbsp;123 to require prominent disclosure about the effects on reported net
income of an entity&#146;s accounting policy decisions with respect to stock-based
employee compensation. In addition, SFAS No.&nbsp;148 amends APB Opinion No.&nbsp;28,
<I>&#147;Interim Financial Reporting&#148;, </I>to require disclosure about those effects in
interim financial information. SFAS No.&nbsp;148 is effective for financial
statements for fiscal years ending after December&nbsp;15, 2002, including certain
amendments to required disclosures related to stock-based compensation included
in condensed financial statements for interim periods beginning after December
15, 2002. The Company has complied with the required disclosure items in SFAS
No.&nbsp;148, and is still evaluating changing to the fair value based method of
accounting for stock-based employee compensation.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2003, the FASB issued FIN No.&nbsp;46, <I>&#147;Consolidation of Variable
Interest Entities.&#148; </I>FIN No.&nbsp;46 requires that companies that control another
entity through interests other than voting interests should consolidate the
controlled entity. FIN No.&nbsp;46 applies to variable interest entities created
after January&nbsp;31, 2003, and to variable interest entities in which an
enterprise obtains an interest after that date. The related disclosure
requirements are effective immediately. The Company has evaluated the
provisions of FIN No.&nbsp;46 and does not believe it to be reasonably possible that
adoption would have a material effect on its financial condition and results of
operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(n)&nbsp; Use of Estimates</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management of AWA has made certain estimates and assumptions relating to
the reporting of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets
and liabilities to prepare these financial statements in conformity with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. Actual results
could differ from those estimates.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(o)&nbsp; Reclassification</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain reclassifications have been made to the prior years&#146; financial
statements to conform to the current year&#146;s presentation.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">79</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>2. Restatement of Previously Reported Amounts</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA has restated its audited financial statements for the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 and
its unaudited financial statements for the first, second and third
quarters of fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. The changes include:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">a change in the timing from the first quarter of 2002 back
to the fourth quarter of 2001 of the non-cash impairment charge of
approximately $39.2&nbsp;million recorded to adjust the carrying value of
owned aircraft to market value and the related non-cash impairment
charge of approximately $64.1&nbsp;million recorded to write off
reorganization value in excess of amounts allocable to identifiable
assets (&#147;ERV&#148;) that arose in connection with AWA&#146;s plan of
reorganization from bankruptcy in 1994, both of which charges were
previously recorded in the first quarter of 2002; and</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">the recognition of a full valuation allowance relating to AWA&#146;s net
deferred tax assets.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">See Note 2 <I>&#147;Restatement of Previously Reported Amounts&#148; </I>in Notes to Financial
Statements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Impairment Charges</I></B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Statement
of Financial Accounting Standards (&#147;SFAS&#148;) No.&nbsp;121 <i>&#147;Accounting for the Impairment of Long-Lived Assets and for
Long-Lived Assets to Be Disposed Of&#148;</i> requires that an impairment analysis be performed whenever circumstances indicate that the carrying amount
of an asset that an entity expects to hold and use may not be recoverable.
</font>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a
result of the adverse impacts on AWA and the airline industry as a
whole resulting from the terrorist events of September&nbsp;11, 2001 and their aftermath, AWA
performed an assessment of
impairment of its owned aircraft during 2001 and again in connection with the preparation of the interim financial statements for the first quarter of
2002.
</font>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of AWA&#146;s assessments, no impairment adjustment was
recorded in the financial statements previously issued for 2001. AWA
recorded an impairment charge of approximately $39.2&nbsp;million in the first
quarter of 2002 to adjust the carrying value of its owned aircraft to reflect market
values at that time. Such accounting treatment was considered appropriate at
the time of the issuance of the applicable financial statements. In connection
with the preparation of the financial statements and the related audit for the fiscal year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002, AWA determined that the more appropriate recognition of
the impairment charge of approximately $39.2&nbsp;million is in the fourth quarter
of 2001 rather than in the first quarter of 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, SFAS No.&nbsp;121 requires that goodwill that arose in a purchase
business combination be allocated, and included as part of the asset base, in
determining recoverability and measuring impairment. AWA did not have goodwill at December&nbsp;31,
2001, but did have a significant amount of unamortized ERV, AWA
determined that a portion of the unamortized ERV balance should have
been allocated to AWA&#146;s owned aircraft in the
impairment analysis performed for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As more fully described in Note 3, <I>&#147;Adoption of New Accounting Standard&#148;</I>
in Notes to Financial Statements, the remaining unamortized balance of ERV was
written-off in the first quarter of 2002, as a cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle upon adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142,
<I>&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The impact of the above described matters is to change the period of
recognition for these non-cash costs between late 2001 and early
2002. See Note 18,
<I>&#147;Quarterly Financial Data (Unaudited)&#148; </I>in Notes to Financial
Statements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B><I>Deferred Income Taxes</I></B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS No.&nbsp;109 <I>&#147;Accounting for Income Taxes&#148; </I>requires that a valuation
allowance be established when it is &#147;more likely than not&#148; that all or a
portion of deferred tax assets will not be realized. A review of all available
positive and negative evidence needs to be considered, including the company&#146;s
performance, the market environment in which the company operates, forecasts of
future profitability, the utilization of past tax credits, length of
carryforward periods and similar factors. SFAS No.&nbsp;109 further states that it
is difficult to conclude that a valuation allowance is not needed when there is
negative evidence such as cumulative losses in recent years. Therefore,
cumulative losses weigh heavily in the overall assessment.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">80</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA had
originally reported a net deferred tax liability at December&nbsp;31,
2001. After consideration of the restatement discussed above, AWA had
a net deferred tax asset and was in a cumulative loss position for the three years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. A full valuation allowance has been established
relating to AWA&#146;s net deferred tax asset at December&nbsp;31,
2001, and relating to
tax assets generated by losses in 2002. We expect to continue to record a full
valuation allowance on future tax benefits until we can return to profitability. See Note 10, <I>&#147;Income Taxes&#148; </I>and Note 18, <I>&#147;Quarterly
Financial Data (Unaudited)&#148; </I>in Notes to Financial Statements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a
result of the adjustments discussed above, AWA&#146;s financial
statements for the first three quarters of 2002 and for the year ended 2001
have been restated from amounts previously reported. See Note 18, &#147;Quarterly
Financial Date (Unaudited)&#148; for a summary of the adjustments for these periods
on a quarterly basis. The principal effects of these adjustments on the
accompanying financial statements are set forth below.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>3. Adoption of New Accounting Standard</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2001, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;142, <I>&#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible
Assets.&#148; </I>SFAS No.&nbsp;142 primarily addresses the accounting for goodwill and
intangible assets subsequent to their acquisition. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 does not
permit the amortization of goodwill as required by APB Opinion No.&nbsp;17,
<I>&#147;Intangible Assets.&#148; </I>Rather, goodwill is subject to a periodic impairment
test, using a two-step process. The first step is to identify a potential
impairment. The second step of the goodwill impairment test measures the
amount of the impairment loss, using a fair value-based approach. Under SFAS
No.&nbsp;142, ERV is reported as goodwill and accounted for in the same manner as
goodwill. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 was effective for fiscal years beginning after December
15, 2001. Upon adoption of this statement on January&nbsp;1, 2002, AWA recorded an
impairment loss of $187.9&nbsp;million, which was supported by an independent
valuation of the Company. The impairment loss was recorded as the cumulative
effect of a change in accounting principle.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table presents reported net income (loss)&nbsp;exclusive of ERV
amortization expense for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000.
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="75%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="51%">&nbsp;</TD>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">(1)&nbsp; Amortization of ERV is not a tax-deductible expense.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>4. Government Guaranteed Loan</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380
million government loan guarantee. This loan triggered concessions and
additional financing (primarily aircraft rent reductions and future financing
commitments), resulting in a restructuring of AWA&#146;s indebtedness and lease
commitments. The major components of the restructuring are:
</FONT>
<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Government Guaranteed Loan &#151; The catalyst for AWA&#146;s restructuring
plan was a $429&nbsp;million loan backed by a $380&nbsp;million federal loan
guarantee. The loan has a seven-year term with ratable amortization in
years three through seven, an interest rate of three month LIBOR plus 40
basis points paid quarterly and annual guarantee fees payable to the
U.S. Treasury Department and other loan participants of 550 basis points
in year one and approximately 800 basis points thereafter.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">81</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>




<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Aircraft Deferrals/Financing &#150; AWA restructured its aircraft purchase
commitment with AVSA, to defer 17 new Airbus aircraft previously
scheduled for delivery in 2003 and 2004 by a total of 505
aircraft-months to 2004 through 2007. New financing commitments were
obtained for 11 aircraft which were either already delivered in 2001 or
scheduled to be delivered in 2002 and 2003. Delivery of two of these
aircraft was subsequently deferred until 2005. In order to obtain the
entire amount of the financing commitment for two of the aircraft, AWA
must achieve a minimum liquidity threshold. As a result, AWA has
financing commitments for all scheduled aircraft deliveries through the
fourth quarter of 2003.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Aircraft Returns/Rent Reductions &#151; Through negotiations with
approximately 20 aircraft lessors, AWA has retired 11 aircraft in 2001
and 2002 to better size its fleet to the current industry demand
environment. For the aircraft that remain, annual rent payments have
been reduced for each of the next six years.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Term-out of Line of Credit &#151; AWA&#146;s $89.9&nbsp;million secured credit
facility was converted into an $89.9&nbsp;million secured term loan maturing
at year-end 2007. The loan has a six-year term with ratable
amortization in years four through six and an interest rate of one month
LIBOR plus 225 basis points from the closing date through December&nbsp;31,
2004 and one month LIBOR plus 475 basis points from January&nbsp;1, 2005 and
thereafter. In addition, AWA will pay interest in kind on the aggregate
outstanding principal amount of the loan at a rate of two percent per
annum from the closing date through December&nbsp;31, 2004. In July 2002,
AWA made a mandatory repayment of approximately $16.7&nbsp;million on the
term loan as a result of a decrease in the fair market value of the
assets securing the loan following the terrorist attacks of September
11, 2001.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">State/City Financing &#151; From the State of Arizona and the City of
Phoenix, AWA received $0.7&nbsp;million in job training grants and $1.5
million in other financing. In March 2003, AWA received $6.9&nbsp;million
through the sale and leaseback of jetways at Phoenix Sky Harbor
International Airport.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">TPG Undertaking &#151; At the request of the ATSB, TPG Partners, L.P., and
its affiliates, owners of all 941,431 shares of America West Holdings
Class&nbsp;A common stock, have undertaken not to dispose of their Class&nbsp;A
stock other than in connection with an offer to acquire all the shares
of the Company&#146;s Class&nbsp;B common stock accepted or approved by the
holders of a majority of the Class&nbsp;B stock. This undertaking is subject
to certain exceptions, including transfers to TPG affiliates, repurchase
of the Class&nbsp;A stock by Holdings and exercise of TPG&#146;s rights to convert
the Class&nbsp;A stock into Class&nbsp;B stock, and will terminate when the
warrants issued in connection with the term loan transactions discussed
below expire or are exercised and the underlying shares of Class&nbsp;B stock
are sold, or TPG and its affiliates no longer hold the Class&nbsp;A stock.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Warrants/Convertible Senior Notes &#151; As compensation for various
elements of the restructuring plan, Holdings issued a warrant to
purchase up to 18.8&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;B common stock to the
federal government and additional warrants to purchase up to 3.8&nbsp;million
shares of its Class&nbsp;B common stock to other loan participants, in each
case at an exercise price of $3 per share and a term of ten years. For
accounting purposes, the warrants were valued at $35.4&nbsp;million, or $1.57
per share, using the Black-Scholes pricing model with the following
assumptions: expected dividend yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest rate
of 4.8%, volatility of 44.9% and an expected life of ten years.
Holdings also issued approximately $104.5&nbsp;million in convertible senior
notes as partial compensation to aircraft lessors. The notes have a
seven-year term and a coupon rate of 7.5% with interest paid in kind for
years one through three. The notes are convertible after three years
into Class&nbsp;B common stock at $12 per share. During 2002, one aircraft
lessor relinquished its interest in approximately $11.8&nbsp;million face
value of the 7.5% convertible notes upon the restructuring of leases for
six Boeing 757-200 aircraft. One aircraft lessor also relinquished its
interest in approximately $1.6&nbsp;million face value of the 7.5%
convertible notes upon the exercise of its put rights to extend the
leases for two Boeing 737-300 aircraft.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the restructuring, Holdings and AWA granted to the
recipients of the notes and warrants certain registration rights. In May 2002,
Holdings and AWA filed a registration statement with the Securities and
Exchange Commission to satisfy their obligations to the recipients of the notes
and warrants. The registration statement covers:
</FONT>
