<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>6. Financial Instruments and Risk Management</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>(a)&nbsp; Fair Value of Financial Instruments</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Cash Equivalents, Short-term Investments and Receivables</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The carrying amount approximates fair value because of the short-term
nature of these instruments.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Investments in Equity Securities</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA owned approximately 28,300 shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock of
Aeroxchange Ltd., an airline industry business-to-business e-commerce exchange,
at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001. The common stock of Aeroxchange is not publicly
traded on a securities exchange, therefore the fair value of AWA&#146;s investment
in Aeroxchange is not readily determinable. Accordingly, the investment was
carried at cost, which approximated $2.8&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2001. In
March 2002, AWA wrote down its investment in Aeroxchange to net realizable
value, recognizing a pretax loss of $2.8&nbsp;million. See Note 15, <I>&#147;Nonoperating
Income (Expenses) &#150; Other, Net.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Warrants</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA is the holder of warrants in a number of on-line ventures that are not
public. The fair value of these warrants is not readily determinable.
Accordingly, the investments are carried at cost, which was not material at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 or 2001.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Long-term Debt</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, the fair value of long-term debt was
approximately $657.9&nbsp;million and $324.4&nbsp;million, respectively. The Company&#146;s
long-term debt with a carrying value of $570.4&nbsp;million and $179.7&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, respectively, approximates fair value because these
borrowings have variable interest rate terms that approximate market interest
rates for similar debt instruments. The fair values of the Company&#146;s other
long-term debt are determined based on quoted market prices if available or
market prices for comparable debt instruments.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">83</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>(b)&nbsp; Fuel Price Risk Management</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under its fuel hedging program, AWA may enter into certain hedging
transactions with approved counterparties for a period generally not exceeding
12&nbsp;months. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, AWA had entered into costless collar
transactions hedging approximately 40% of its projected 2003 fuel requirements.
The fair value of AWA&#146;s financial derivative instruments was a net asset of
approximately $3.6&nbsp;million and $2.2&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001,
respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA is exposed to credit risks in the event any counterparty fails to meet
its obligations. AWA does not anticipate such non-performance as
counterparties are selected based on credit ratings, exposure to any one
counterparty is limited based on formal guidelines and the relative market
positions with such counterparties are closely monitored.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>(c)&nbsp; Concentration of Credit Risk</B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA does not believe it is subject to any significant concentration of
credit risk. Most of AWA&#146;s receivables result from tickets sold to individual
passengers through the use of major credit cards or from tickets sold by other
airlines and used by passengers on AWA. These receivables are short-term,
generally being settled shortly after the sale.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>7. Advances to Parent Company and Affiliate</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, AWA had net advances to Holdings of $257.8
million, which were classified in AWA&#146;s balance sheet as current assets. In
January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380&nbsp;million
government loan guarantee. See Note 4, <I>&#147;Government Guaranteed Loan.&#148; </I>The
terms of this loan and AWA&#146;s secured term loan restrict Holdings&#146; and AWA&#146;s
ability to incur additional indebtedness or issue equity unless the proceeds of
those transactions are used to prepay the government guaranteed loan and the
term loan. Accordingly, as a result of this transaction, AWA&#146;s net advances to
Holdings have been classified in &#147;Other Assets&#148; on AWA&#146;s balance sheet.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2002, AWA&#146;s net advances to Holdings were reduced by approximately $34
million as the result of income tax refunds received in 2002. See Note 10,
<I>&#147;Income Taxes.&#148; </I>At December&nbsp;31, 2002, AWA had net advances to Holdings of
approximately $223.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, AWA had net advances of $8.1&nbsp;million to TLC, a
wholly owned subsidiary of Holdings, including $16.0&nbsp;million advanced by AWA to
TLC under a revolving line of credit. In January 2002, upon closing of the
government guaranteed loan, TLC repaid the $16.0&nbsp;million loan in full to AWA.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, AWA had a net payable of $1.8&nbsp;million due
principally to TLC. This payable, which is primarily related to credit card
receipts collected by AWA for vacation packages sold by TLC, was classified in
AWA&#146;s balance sheet as a current liability.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">84</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

</FONT>

    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Equipment notes payable, variable interest rates of 2.75% to 3.00%, averaging

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(a)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In December 1999, AWA entered into a $125&nbsp;million senior secured
revolving credit facility with a group of financial institutions that had
a three-year term. Borrowings under this credit facility accrued interest
at either the &#147;base rate&#148; (prime rate or the rate which is 1/2 of 1% in
excess of the Federal Funds Effective Rate) or the &#147;adjusted eurodollar
rate&#148; (LIBOR rate adjusted for certain reserve requirements in respect to
&#147;Eurodollar liabilities&#148;) plus the applicable margin based on Moody&#146;s
rating of AWA&#146;s senior unsecured notes. The credit agreement was secured
by certain assets of AWA. As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, AWA had drawn $89.9
million against its available line of credit which was classified in
current maturities of long-term debt in the Company&#146;s consolidated balance
sheet. In January 2002, upon closing of the $429&nbsp;million loan supported
by a $380&nbsp;million government loan guarantee (see Note 4, <I>&#147;Government
Guaranteed Loan&#148;</I>), AWA&#146;s secured credit facility was converted into an
$89.9&nbsp;million secured term loan maturing at year-end 2007. The loan has a
six-year term with ratable amortization in years four through six and an
interest rate of one month LIBOR plus 225 basis points from the closing
date through December&nbsp;31, 2004 and one month LIBOR plus 475 basis points
from January&nbsp;1, 2005 and thereafter. In addition, AWA will pay interest
in kind on the aggregate outstanding principle amount of the loan at a
rate of two percent per annum from the closing date through December&nbsp;31,
2004. In July 2002, AWA made a mandatory repayment of approximately $16.7
million on its $89.9&nbsp;million term loan as a result of a decrease in the
fair market value of the assets securing the loan following the terrorist
attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001. Collateral for the loan consists of
aircraft, spare engines, rotable aircraft parts inventory and a
maintenance facility. AWA and the lenders also amended certain provisions
in the loan agreement related to the collateral appraisal procedures. The
balance at December&nbsp;31, 2002 includes $1.6&nbsp;million of interest payable in
kind through December&nbsp;31, 2002.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(b)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">The 10 3/4% Senior Unsecured Notes mature on September&nbsp;1, 2005 and
interest is payable in arrears semi-annually. The 10 3/4% Senior
Unsecured Notes may be redeemed at the option of the Company at any time
in whole or from time to time in part, at a redemption price equal to the
following percentage of principal redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid
interest to the date of redemption, if redeemed during the 12-month period
beginning:</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<CENTER>

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(c)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In January 2002, Holdings issued approximately $104.5&nbsp;million in
convertible senior notes, which are guaranteed by AWA, to certain aircraft
lessors as compensation for various elements of the restructuring plan.
The notes have a seven-year term, a coupon rate of 7.5% with interest paid
in kind for years one through three. The notes are convertible after
three years into Class&nbsp;B common stock at $12 per share. The notes may be
redeemed at the election of the Company, as a whole or in part, at any
time before January&nbsp;18, 2005, at a redemption price equal to $1,000 per
$1,000 principal amount of the notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid
interest, if any, to but excluding the date of redemption if (1)&nbsp;the
trading price of the common stock has exceeded 120% of the conversion
price then in effect for at least 20 trading days within a period of 30
consecutive trading days ending on the trading day before the date of
mailing of the notice of provisional redemption, and</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">85</FONT>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">For financial reporting purposes, AWA recorded the convertible senior notes
at their fair market value on the date of issuance. The balance at December
31, 2002 is net of an unamortized discount of $2.7&nbsp;million and includes $6.2
million of interest payable in kind through December&nbsp;31, 2002. See Note 4,
<I>&#147;Government Guaranteed Loan.&#148;</I></FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(d)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">The industrial development revenue bonds are due April 2023. Interest at
6.3% is payable semiannually (April 1 and October 1). The bonds are
subject to optional redemption prior to the maturity date on or after
April&nbsp;1, 2008, in whole or in part, on any interest payment date at the
following redemption prices: 102&nbsp;percent on April 1 or October&nbsp;1, 2008;
101&nbsp;percent on April 1 or October&nbsp;1, 2009; and 100&nbsp;percent on April&nbsp;1,
2010 and thereafter.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">(e)</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan backed by a $380&nbsp;million
federal loan guarantee. The loan has a seven-year term with ratable
amortization in years three through seven, an interest rate of three month
LIBOR plus 40 basis points paid quarterly and guarantee fees payable to
the U.S. Treasury Department and other loan participants of 550 basis
points in year one and approximately 800 basis points thereafter. See
Note 4, <I>&#147;Government Guaranteed Loan.&#148;</I></FONT></TD>

</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Secured financings totaling $132.9&nbsp;million are collateralized by assets,
primarily aircraft, engines, simulators, rotable aircraft parts and AWA&#146;s
hangar facility, with a net book value of $316.6&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the estimated maturities of long-term debt are as
follows:
</FONT>
<CENTER>
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="55%">

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain of the Company&#146;s long-term debt agreements contain minimum cash
balance requirements and other covenants with which Holdings and AWA are in
compliance. Certain of these covenants restrict the Company&#146;s ability to pay
cash dividends on its common stock and make certain other restricted payments
(as specified therein). Finally, AWA&#146;s long-term debt agreements contain
cross-default provisions, which may be triggered by defaults by AWA under other
agreements relating to indebtedness. As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, AWA had
suspended payment under certain aircraft leases and, as a result, had received
notices of default from certain aircraft lessors. In January 2002, AWA paid in
full approximately $81&nbsp;million in deferred aircraft lease payments
simultaneously with the funding of the $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380
million government loan guarantee, thereby curing the defaults. See <I>&#147;Risk
Factors Relating to America West and Industry Related Risks &#151; Our high level of
debt and fixed costs limits our ability to fund general corporate requirements,
limits our flexibility in responding to competitive developments and increases
our vulnerability to adverse economic and industry conditions.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">86</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>9. Commitments and Contingencies</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(a)&nbsp; Leases</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company had 133 aircraft under operating
leases with remaining terms ranging from three months to approximately 22
years. In January 2002, AWA closed a $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380
million government loan guarantee that resulted in a restructuring of its
aircraft lease commitments. As a result, AWA has retired 11 aircraft in 2001
and 2002 to better size its fleet to the current industry demand environment.
In addition, under the restructured lease agreements, annual rent payments have
been reduced for each of the next six years (see Note 4, <I>&#147;Government
Guaranteed Loan&#148;</I>). Certain of these leases contain put options pursuant to
which the lessors could require AWA to renew the leases for periods ranging
from eight months to 8.5&nbsp;years or call options pursuant to which the lessors
could require AWA to return the aircraft to the lessors upon receipt of four to
nine months written notice. The Company also has options to purchase certain
of the aircraft at fair market values at the end of the lease terms. Certain
of the agreements require security deposits, minimum return provisions and
maintenance reserve payments.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of the rent restructuring associated with the government
guaranteed loan, one aircraft lease was amended to include a bargain purchase
option. As a result, this lease has been classified as a capital lease in
accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;13, <I>&#147;Accounting for Leases,&#148; </I>as amended, with an asset
value of $16.9&nbsp;million and corresponding lease obligation of $14.5&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2002, one aircraft lessor exercised its put right under its
aircraft lease agreement to extend the lease for one Boeing 737-300 aircraft
for an additional 13&nbsp;months. Upon exercising this right, the lessor agreed to
relinquish its interest in approximately $0.7&nbsp;million face value of 7.5%
convertible senior notes it received as compensation for certain concessions
granted under the restructuring completed on January&nbsp;18, 2002. In October
2002, the same aircraft lessor exercised its put right to extend the lease for
another Boeing 737-300 aircraft for an additional 18&nbsp;months. Upon exercising
the right, the lessor agreed to relinquish its interest in approximately $0.9
million face value of 7.5% convertible senior notes.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 2002, AWA restructured the leases for six of its Boeing 757-200
aircraft to improve lease rental rates and other terms. Prior to the
restructuring, AWA subleased the six aircraft from The Boeing Company
(&#147;Boeing&#148;), who in turn leased the aircraft from five different head lessors.
Under the restructuring, AWA terminated the subleases with Boeing and assumed,
amended and restated the existing head leases for each aircraft. Upon closing
of the transactions, AWA paid approximately $11.8&nbsp;million in security deposits
and advance rental payments to the head lessors, net of a refund from Boeing
for prorated prepaid rent under the subleases, prorated accrued rent under the
head leases and cash deposits for the estimated cost of certain maintenance
work required to be performed on the aircraft prior to their return to Boeing.
As a result of these transactions, Boeing also relinquished its interest in
approximately $11.2&nbsp;million face value of 7.5% convertible notes it received as
compensation for certain concessions granted under the restructuring completed
on January&nbsp;18, 2002. Furthermore, AWA issued a $4.9&nbsp;million promissory note to
Boeing for the value of the concessions realized with respect to these six
aircraft prior to the termination of the subleases, of which approximately $2.5
million was paid in 2002. The promissory note has a fixed interest rate of 10%
and matures in June 2003. The restructured leases have a remaining term of
approximately six years and are being accounted for as operating leases.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September 2002, two aircraft lessors exercised their put rights under
their aircraft lease agreements to extend the leases for two Airbus A320
aircraft for an additional 12&nbsp;months each.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In November 2002, one aircraft lessor exercised its put rights under its
aircraft lease agreement to extend the leases for four Boeing 737-300 aircraft
for an additional 18&nbsp;months each.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company also leases certain terminal space, ground facilities and
computer and other equipment under noncancelable operating leases.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">87</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Rent expense (excluding landing fees) was approximately $409&nbsp;million, $457
million and $427&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001 and 2000,
respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Collectively, the operating lease agreements require security deposits
with lessors of $20.9&nbsp;million and bank letters of credit of $13.8&nbsp;million. The
letters of credit are collateralized by $13.8&nbsp;million of restricted cash.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(b)&nbsp; Revenue Bonds</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June 1999, Series&nbsp;1999 special facility revenue bonds (&#147;new bonds&#148;)
were issued by a municipality to fund the retirement of the Series&nbsp;1994A bonds
(&#147;old bonds&#148;) and the construction of a new concourse with 14 gates at Terminal
4 in Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport in support of AWA&#146;s strategic
growth plan. The new bonds are due June 2019 with interest accruing at 6.25%
per annum payable semiannually on June 1 and December&nbsp;1, commencing on December
1, 1999. The new bonds are subject to optional redemption prior to the
maturity date on or after June&nbsp;1, 2009 in whole or in part, on any interest
payment date at the following redemption prices: 101% on June 1 or December&nbsp;1,
2009; 100.5% on June 1 or December&nbsp;1, 2010; and 100% on June&nbsp;1, 2011 and
thereafter. In accordance with EITF Issue No.&nbsp;97-10, <I>&#147;The Effect of Lessee
Involvement in Asset Construction,&#148; </I>the Company accounts for this as an
operating lease.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
connection with these bonds, AWA entered into an Amended and Restated
Airport Use Agreement, pursuant to which AWA agreed to make
sufficient payments to the Industrial Development Authority
(&#147;IDA&#148;) to cover the principal and interest of the bonds
and to indemnify the IDA for any claims arising out of the issuance
and sale of the bonds and the use and occupancy of the concourses
financed by these bonds and the old bonds. At December&nbsp;31, 2002,
the outstanding principal amount of the bonds was $21.8&nbsp;million.
The Company estimates its remaining payments to cover the principal
and interest of these bonds will be approximately $44.3&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(c)&nbsp; Aircraft Acquisitions</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2002, upon closing of the $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a $380
million government loan guarantee, AWA restructured its aircraft purchase
commitment to AVSA. As a result, 17 new Airbus aircraft previously scheduled
for delivery in 2003 and 2004 were deferred by a total of 505 aircraft-months
to 2004 through 2007. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, AWA had firm commitments to AVSA
for a total of 15 Airbus A318-100, one Airbus A319-100 and five Airbus A320-200
aircraft with delivery through 2007 at a cost of approximately $800&nbsp;million.
The agreement with AVSA also includes options to purchase an additional 17 A320
family aircraft during 2006 through 2008 and purchase rights for an additional
25 aircraft in the A320 family of aircraft for delivery in 2005 to 2008.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has an agreement with International Aero Engines (&#147;IAE&#148;) which
provides for the purchase by the Company of four new V2500-A5 spare engines
scheduled for delivery through 2004 for use on certain of the A320 fleet. At
December&nbsp;31, 2002, the four engines have an estimated aggregate cost of $19
million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table reflects estimated cash payments under the
restructured aircraft purchase agreement with AVSA and the IAE engine contract.
Actual payments may vary due to inflation factor adjustments and changes in
the delivery schedule of the equipment. The estimated cash payments include
progress payments that will be made in cash, as opposed to being financed under
an existing progress payment financing facility.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">88</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In May 2001, America West Airlines 2001-1 Pass Through Trusts issued
$427.2&nbsp;million of Pass Through Trust Certificates in connection with the
financing of nine Airbus A319 aircraft and five Airbus A320 aircraft. The
combined effective interest rate on this financing is 7.66% on a fixed rate
equivalent basis at the time of closing.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Pass Through Trust Certificates were issued by separate trusts that
hold equipment notes issued upon delivery of each financed aircraft. Proceeds
from the certificates were deposited in an escrow account pending their
application to purchase the equipment notes. The equipment notes were issued,
at AWA&#146;s election, either by AWA in connection with a mortgage financing of the
aircraft or by a separate owner trust in connection with a leveraged lease
financing of the aircraft. In the case of a leveraged lease financing, the
owner trust then leased the aircraft to AWA. In both cases, the equipment
notes are secured by a security interest in the aircraft. The pass through
trust certificates are not direct obligations of, nor guaranteed by, Holdings
or AWA. However, in the case of mortgage financings, the equipment notes
issued to the trusts are direct obligations of AWA and in the case of leveraged
lease financing, the leases are direct obligations of AWA.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Of the 14 aircraft financed under the 2001-1 Pass Through Trusts, 11 were
delivered in 2001, including three in the fourth quarter of 2001. One aircraft
was delivered in the first quarter of 2002 and two were delivered in the second
quarter of 2002. Except for the aircraft delivered in the first quarter of
2002, which was already financed as a leveraged lease upon delivery, the
acquisition of each aircraft was initially structured as a mortgage financing
and subsequently converted into a leveraged lease financing in sale-leaseback
transactions. In connection with the purchase of the two aircraft delivered in
the second quarter of 2002, AWA issued $64.2&nbsp;million of equipment notes. In
June 2002, AWA converted the mortgage financing of the three aircraft delivered
in the fourth quarter of 2001 and the two aircraft delivered in the second
quarter of 2002 into a leveraged lease financing by entering into
sale-leaseback transactions. As a result, approximately $161.2&nbsp;million of the
equipment notes were assumed, on a non-recourse basis, by the owner trustees
that purchased the aircraft from AWA.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2002, in conjunction with the $429&nbsp;million loan supported by a
$380&nbsp;million government loan guarantee, AWA obtained new financing commitments
for 11 aircraft which were either already delivered in 2001 or scheduled to be
delivered in 2002 and 2003. Delivery of two of these aircraft was subsequently
deferred until 2005. In order to obtain the entire amount of the financing
commitment for two of the aircraft, AWA must achieve an established minimum
liquidity threshold. As a result, AWA has financing commitments for all
scheduled aircraft deliveries through the fourth quarter of 2003. See Note 4,
<I>&#147;Government Guaranteed Loan.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(d)&nbsp; Sale-Leaseback Transactions</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As part of the restructuring completed on January&nbsp;18, 2002, AWA committed
to the sale and leaseback of eight aircraft. The sale and leaseback of five of
these aircraft was completed in June 2002 and resulted in pretax losses of
approximately $2.4&nbsp;million. The sale and leaseback of one aircraft was
completed in November 2002 and resulted in a pretax loss of approximately $1.4
million. The losses on the sale-leaseback transactions, which were subject to
a firm commitment in January 2002, were accrued in the accompanying statements
of operations classified in <I>&#147;Special Charges&#148; </I>in the first quarter of 2002.
See Note 14, <I>&#147;Special Charges.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January 2001, AWA borrowed $49.4&nbsp;million from the America West Airlines
2000-1 Pass Through Trusts to fund the acquisition of two new A319 Airbus
aircraft. In March 2001, AWA entered into a sale-leaseback transaction whereby
the Company sold these aircraft resulting in a $9.6&nbsp;million gain. This gain
was deferred and is being amortized over the term of the operating leases,
which approximates 22&nbsp;years, as a reduction in rent expense.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the second and third quarters of 2001, AWA borrowed $232.0&nbsp;million from
the America West Airlines 2001-1 Pass Through Trusts to fund the acquisition of
eight new A319 Airbus aircraft. In October 2001, AWA completed the sale of
these eight aircraft as part of a sale-leaseback transaction. The $34.1
million gain resulting from this transaction was deferred and is being
amortized over the term of the operating leases, which approximates 20&nbsp;years,
as a reduction in rent expense.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September 2001, AWA completed the sale of two owned aircraft engines,
with a combined net book value of $10.9&nbsp;million, for approximately $10.0
million as part of a sale-leaseback transaction. The resulting $0.9&nbsp;million
pretax loss on this transaction was recognized in the accompanying statements
of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, classified in <I>&#147;Nonoperating
Income (Expense) &#151; Other, Net.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">89</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In October 2001, AWA completed the sale of two owned A320 flight
simulators as part of a sale-leaseback transaction. The flight simulators,
with a combined net book value of $14.6&nbsp;million, were sold for approximately
$17.4&nbsp;million. The gain resulting from this transaction was deferred and is
being amortized over the term of the operating lease, which approximates nine
years, as a reduction in rent expense.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(e)&nbsp; Contingent Legal Obligations</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holdings and its subsidiaries are parties to various legal proceedings,
including some purporting to be class action suits, and some which demand large
monetary damages or other relief, which, if granted, would require significant
expenditures. In certain cases where it is probable that the outcome will
result in monetary damages, the Company has reviewed available information and
determined that the best estimate of losses to be incurred related to these
cases is $2&nbsp;million, which has been accrued. For those cases where a loss is
possible, or cases where a range of loss is probable but no amount within the
range is a better estimate than any other amount, the estimated amount of
exposure ranges from $0 to $25&nbsp;million. In these instances, no accrual has
been recorded.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>(f)&nbsp; General Guarantees and Indemnifications</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is the lessee under many aircraft financing agreements
(including leveraged lease financings of aircraft under the pass through
trusts) and real estate leases. It is common in such transactions for the
Company as the lessee to agree to indemnify the lessor and other related third
parties for the manufacture, design, ownership, financing, use, operation and
maintenance of the aircraft, and for tort liabilities that arise out of or
relate to the Company&#146;s use or occupancy of the leased asset. In some cases,
this indemnity extends to related liabilities arising from the negligence of
the indemnified parties, but usually excludes any liabilities caused by their
gross negligence or willful misconduct. Additionally, in the case of real
estate leases, the Company typically indemnifies such parties for any
environmental liability that arises out of or relates to the Company&#146;s use of
the leased premises. The Company expects that it would be covered by insurance
(subject to deductibles) for most tort liabilities and related indemnities
described above with respect to leased real estate and operated aircraft.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>10. Income Taxes</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA is included In Holdings&#146; consolidated income tax return. Income tax
expense in the accompanying statements of operations has been determined on a
separate company basis.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA recorded income tax expense (benefit)&nbsp;as follows:

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA&#146;s emergence from bankruptcy reorganization in 1994 and the associated
implementation of fresh start reporting gave rise to significant items of
expense for financial reporting purposes that are not deductible for income tax
purposes. In large measure, it is these nondeductible (for income tax
purposes) expenses that result in an effective tax expense (benefit)&nbsp;rate for
financial reporting purposes that differs from the current federal statutory
income tax rate of 35% for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">90</FONT>

</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, AWA has available net operating loss
carryforwards (&#147;NOL&#148;) and business tax credit carryforwards for federal income
tax purposes of approximately $399.6&nbsp;million and $1.9&nbsp;million, respectively.
The NOL expire during the years 2007 through 2009 while the business credit
carryforwards expire during the years 2003 through 2006. However, such
carryforwards are not available to offset federal (and in certain
circumstances, state) alternative minimum taxable income. Further, as a result
of a statutory &#147;ownership change&#148; (as defined for purposes of Section&nbsp;382 of
the Internal Revenue Code) that occurred as a result of AWA&#146;s reorganization in
1994, AWA&#146;s ability to utilize its NOL and business tax credit carryforwards
may be restricted.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February 2002, Holdings filed its 2001 consolidated income tax return
with the IRS, which included a claim to carryback losses incurred in 2001 to
the tax years 1999 and 2000. This resulted in a refund of approximately $33.9
million, of which substantially all was received in the first quarter of 2002.
In March 2002, Holdings filed a revised claim for carryback losses under the
Job Creation and Workers Assistance Act of 2002, resulting in an additional
refund of approximately $26.4&nbsp;million which was received in the second quarter
of 2002. Holdings will be able to carryback a portion of its 2002 loss to
prior years and obtain a refund of $3.2&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Composition of Deferred Tax Items</I></B>:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred income taxes reflect the net tax effects of temporary differences
between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting
purposes and the amounts used for income tax purposes. As of December&nbsp;31, the
significant components of AWA&#146;s deferred tax assets and liabilities are a
result of the temporary differences related to the items described as follows:
</FONT>
<CENTER>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">(77,987</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap><FONT size="2">)</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">(33,387</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap><FONT size="2">)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD colspan="3"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD colspan="3"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">112,442</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">96,043</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD colspan="3"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#eeeeee">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Net deferred tax asset (liability)</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2"> &#151;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2"> &#151;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="4" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="4" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS No.&nbsp;109, <I>&#147;Accounting for Income Taxes,&#148; </I>requires that a valuation
allowance be established when it is &#147;more likely than not&#148; that all or a
portion of deferred tax assets will not be realized. A review of all available
positive and negative evidence needs to be considered, including the company&#146;s
performance, the market environment in which the company operates, forecasts of
future profitability, the utilization of past tax credits, length of
carryforward periods and similar factors. SFAS No.&nbsp;109 further states that it
is difficult to conclude that a valuation allowance is not needed when there is
negative evidence such as cumulative losses in recent years.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">91</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Therefore, cumulative losses weigh heavily in the overall assessment.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company was in a cumulative loss position for the three years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001. Accordingly, a full valuation allowance has been
established relating to the Company&#146;s net deferred tax assets as December&nbsp;31,
2001, and to tax benefits generated in 2002. We expect to continue to record a
full valuation allowance on future tax benefits until we can sustain an
appropriate level of profitability.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>11. Capital Stock</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Common Stock</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The holders of common stock are entitled to one vote for each share of
stock held by the holder. Holders of common stock have no right to cumulate
their votes in the election of directors. The holders of common stock are
entitled to receive, when and if declared by the Board of Directors, out of the
assets of AWA which are by law available, dividends payable either in cash, in
stock or otherwise.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B><I>Warrants</I></B>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As compensation for various elements of the Company&#146;s financial
restructuring completed in January 2002, Holdings issued a warrant to purchase
18.8&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;B common stock to the federal government and
additional warrants to purchase 3.8&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;B common stock
to other loan participants, in each case at an exercise price of $3 per share
and a term of ten years. For accounting purposes, the warrants were valued at
$35.4&nbsp;million, or $1.57 per share, using the Black-Scholes pricing model with
the following assumptions: expected dividend yield of 0.0%, risk-free interest
rate of 4.8%, volatility of 44.9% and an expected life of ten years. The
warrants were recorded by AWA as a non-cash capital contribution in the
accompanying statements of stockholder&#146;s equity and comprehensive income.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>12. Other Comprehensive Income (Loss)</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other comprehensive income (loss)&nbsp;includes changes in the fair value of
derivative financial instruments that qualify for hedge accounting. For the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, AWA recorded a total comprehensive loss
of $376.4&nbsp;million and $241.7&nbsp;million, respectively. The difference between net
loss and comprehensive loss for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001 is
detailed in the following table:
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>13. Employee Benefit Plan</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA has a 401(k) defined contribution plan, covering essentially all
employees of AWA. Participants may contribute from 1 to 15% of their pretax
earnings to a maximum of $11,000 in 2002. AWA&#146;s matching contribution is
determined annually by the Board of Directors. AWA&#146;s contribution expense to
the plan totaled $8.6&nbsp;million, $8.0&nbsp;million and $8.9&nbsp;million in 2002, 2001 and
2000, respectively.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">92</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

special charge are as follows:

    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Revision of estimate for second quarter 2001 special charge</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">(4,000</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap><FONT size="2">)</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">(4,000</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap><FONT size="2">)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="1" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Total</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">21,030</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right"><FONT size="2">60,255</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
    <TD colspan="2"><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></DIV></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="4" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><HR size="4" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</CENTER>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Of this amount, approximately $10.3&nbsp;million, principally related to losses
on sale-leaseback transactions, fleet restructuring costs, professional fees
and severance was accrued.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter of 2002, AWA recorded a $2.0&nbsp;million reduction in
special charges due to a revision of the estimated costs related to the early
termination of certain aircraft leases.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In April 2001, AWA implemented a cost reduction plan to respond to a
softening economy. The plan included a slowing of the airline&#146;s growth through
the return of seven older 737-300 leased aircraft to the lessors in the second
half of 2001 and January 2002 and significant reductions in overhead due in
part to select reductions-in-force of management, administrative and clerical
personnel. AWA recorded a pretax charge of $35.7&nbsp;million in the second quarter
of 2001 related to the earlier-than-planned aircraft returns and
reductions-in-force.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the fourth quarter of 2001, AWA recorded a pretax special charge of
$106.0&nbsp;million related to the impairment of owned aircraft and
engines as a result of declines in market value resulting from the
terrorist attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001 and their aftermath. Fair value for purposes of determining impairment was determined by independent appraisal and the impairment charge
included an allocation of unamortized ERV at December&nbsp;31, 2001 of approximately $64.1 million. Special charges for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 also include charges for the early termination of leases for one A320 and one 737-300 aircraft.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table presents the payments and other settlements made
during 2002 and the remaining special charge accruals as of December&nbsp;31, 2002.
</FONT>
<CENTER>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>15. Nonoperating Income (Expense) &#151; Other, Net</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the airline compensation provisions of the Air Transportation Safety
and System Stabilization Act (the &#147;Act&#148;), each air carrier was entitled to
receive the lesser of: (i)&nbsp;its direct and incremental losses for the period
September&nbsp;11, 2001 to December&nbsp;31, 2001 or (ii)&nbsp;its proportional available seat
mile allocation (based on available seat miles for August 2001) of the $4.5
billion compensation available under the Act. In 2001, AWA received $98.2
million under the Act from the United States government and expected to
receive, based on its losses and its share of available seat miles, at least an
additional $10.0&nbsp;million. In accordance with EITF Issue No.&nbsp;01-10, <I>&#147;Accounting
for the Impact of the Terrorist Attacks of September&nbsp;11, 2001,&#148; </I>AWA recognized
$108.2&nbsp;million of federal government assistance in 2001 as nonoperating income
because direct and incremental losses incurred during 2001 exceeded that
amount. In July 2002, AWA received an additional $12.3&nbsp;million under the Act.
Accordingly, $10.0&nbsp;million was credited against the receivable established in
2001 and $2.3&nbsp;million was recognized as nonoperating income in the second
quarter of 2002. In August 2002, AWA received an additional payment of $6.2
million under the Act, which was recognized as nonoperating income in the third
quarter of 2002.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March 2002, AWA wrote down its investment in Aeroxchange, an e-commerce
entity, which was carried at cost, to net realizable value recognizing a pretax
loss of $2.8&nbsp;million. See Note 6, <I>&#147;Financial Instruments and Risk Management &#150;
(a)&nbsp;Fair Value of Financial Instruments &#150; Investments in Equity Securities.&#148;</I>
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September 2001, AWA completed the sale of two owned aircraft engines,
with a combined net book value of $10.9&nbsp;million, for approximately $10.0
million as part of a sale leaseback transaction, resulting in a $0.9&nbsp;million
pretax loss.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July 2001, AWA recognized a pretax gain of approximately $1.1&nbsp;million
from the sale of 62,240 warrants to purchase common stock of Expedia.com.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September 2000, AWA recorded an $8.8&nbsp;million pretax unrealized gain on
the Company&#146;s investment in one million shares of GetThere.com common stock.
AWA sold all one million shares of GetThere.com for approximately $17.8&nbsp;million
in October 2000.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In March 2000, AWA sold 500,000 warrants to purchase common stock of
Priceline.com, Inc. for approximately $18.0&nbsp;million, resulting in a pretax gain
of approximately $15.5&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>17. Related Party Transactions</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As part of our reorganization in 1994, Continental Airlines and AWA
entered into an alliance agreement which included code sharing arrangements,
reciprocal frequent flyer programs and ground handling operations. In March
2002, AWA received notice from Continental of its intention to terminate the
code sharing and frequent flyer agreements between the two airlines, effective
April&nbsp;26, 2002. Two of Continental&#146;s directors are managing partners of Texas
Pacific Group, which, through TPG Advisors, Inc., effectively controls the
voting power of Holdings. See <I>&#147;Risk Factors Relating to America West and
Industry Related Risks &#151; The stockholders who effectively control the</I>
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">94</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>AMERICA WEST AIRLINES, INC.<BR>
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS &#151; CONTINUED</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>voting power of Holdings could take actions that would favor their own
personal interests to the detriment of our interests.&#148; </I>AWA paid Continental
approximately $25.5&nbsp;million, $30.1&nbsp;million and $32.4&nbsp;million and also received
approximately $15.9&nbsp;million, $22.0&nbsp;million and $25.5&nbsp;million in 2002, 2001 and
2000, respectively, from Continental pursuant to these agreements.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA provides air transportation and certain administrative services to The
Leisure Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Holdings that was formed on
January&nbsp;1, 1998. The cost of air transportation and administrative services
are negotiated on an arms length basis. AWA had net air transportation sales
to TLC of $44.5&nbsp;million, $60.2&nbsp;million and $55.3&nbsp;million, respectively, in
2002, 2001 and 2000, and also received $1.3&nbsp;million in each of those years
under the services agreement.
</FONT>

    <TD width="96%"><FONT size="2">Includes a $47.9&nbsp;million pretax gain related to a federal grant

Act to offset losses resulting from the September&nbsp;11, 2001 terrorist
attacks, $2.7&nbsp;million of pretax special charges related to the early
termination of aircraft leases and an $8.8&nbsp;million pretax gain from an
insurance settlement. Also includes $106.0&nbsp;million of pretax special
charges related to the impairment of ERV and owned aircraft and engines
and the early termination of aircraft leases.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>19. Segment Disclosures</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AWA is one reportable operating segment. Accordingly, the segment
reporting financial data required by SFAS No.&nbsp;131 is included in the
accompanying balance sheets and statements of operations.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>20. Subsequent Event</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Elimination of Hub Operations in Columbus, Ohio</I></FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February 2003, AWA announced that it is eliminating hub operations in
Columbus, Ohio and, as a result, will be phasing 12 regional jets out of the
America West Express fleet. Between early April and mid-June of 2003, AWA will
gradually downsize the hub from 49 daily departures to 15 destinations to a
planned four mainline flights per day to Phoenix and Las Vegas. With the
downsizing of Columbus, AWA must eliminate service to New York City LaGuardia
Airport because perimeter rules at the airport prohibit flights beyond 1,500
miles. This precludes service from AWA&#146;s hubs in Phoenix and Las Vegas. In
the first, second and third quarters of 2003, the Company expects to record a
pretax special charge of approximately $10 to $15&nbsp;million resulting from the
elimination of its Columbus hub operations. The charge is related to the costs
to terminate certain contracts, the write-off of leasehold improvements and
employee transfer and severance expenses.
</FONT>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2">96</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<!-- link1 "PART III" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="013"></A></DIV>
<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>PART III</B>
</FONT>
<!-- link2 "ITEM 10. DIRECTORS AND EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF THE REGISTRANTS" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="014"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>ITEM 10.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;DIRECTORS AND EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF THE REGISTRANTS</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Information respecting continuing directors and nominees of the Company is
set forth under the caption <I>&#147;Election of Directors&#148; </I>in Holdings&#146; Proxy
Statement relating to its 2003 Annual Meeting of Stockholders and is
incorporated by reference into this Form&nbsp;10-K Report. The Proxy Statement will
be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in accordance with Rule
14a-6(c) promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the
&#147;Exchange Act.&#148;) With the exception of the foregoing information and other
information specifically incorporated by reference into this Form&nbsp;10-K Report,
the Proxy Statement is not being filed as a part hereof. Information respecting
executive officers of Holdings is set forth at Part I of this Report.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Information respecting compliance with Section&nbsp;16(a) of the Exchange Act
is set forth under the caption <I>&#147;Section&nbsp;16(a) Beneficial Ownership Reporting
Compliance&#148; </I>in the Proxy Statement and is incorporated by references into this
Form&nbsp;10-K Report.
</FONT>
<!-- link2 "ITEM 11. EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="015"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>ITEM 11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Information concerning executive compensation required by Item&nbsp;11 is set
forth under the captions <I>&#147;Executive Compensation,&#148; &#147;Stock Option Grants and
Exercises,&#148; &#147;Employment Agreements&#148; </I>and <I>&#147;Compensation Committee Interlocks&#148; </I>in
the Proxy Statement and is incorporated by reference into this Form&nbsp;10-K
Report.
</FONT>
<!-- link2 "ITEM 12. SECURITY OWNERSHIP OF CERTAIN BENEFICIAL OWNERS AND MANAGEMENT" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="016"></A></DIV>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>ITEM 12.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SECURITY OWNERSHIP OF CERTAIN BENEFICIAL OWNERS AND MANAGEMENT</B>

management required by Item&nbsp;12 is set forth under the caption <I>&#147;Security
Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners and Management&#148; </I>in the Proxy Statement
and is incorporated by reference into this Form&nbsp;10-K Report.
</FONT>
<!-- link2 "ITEM 13. CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED TRANSACTIONS" -->

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%" align="left" nowrap><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">Based on their evaluation of our disclosure controls and procedures
conducted within 90&nbsp;days of the date of filing this report on Form&nbsp;10-K,
our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer have concluded
that the disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rules
13a-14(c) and 15d-14(c) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as
amended) of Holdings and AWA are effective.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="93%"><FONT size="2">There were no significant changes in the internal controls of Holdings and
AWA or in other factors that could significantly affect these controls
subsequent to the date of their evaluation.</FONT></TD>

caused this report to be signed on its behalf by the undersigned, thereunto
duly authorized.

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>POWER OF ATTORNEY</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We, the undersigned, directors and officers of America West Holdings
Corporation, do hereby severally constitute and appoint W. Douglas Parker and
Linda M. Mitchell and each or any of them, our true and lawful attorneys and
agents, with full power of substitution and resubstitution, for him or her and
in his or her name, place and stead, in any and all capacities, to sign any and
all amendments to the Registrant&#146;s Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the fiscal
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, and to file the same with all exhibits thereto,
and all other documents in connection therewith, with the Securities and
Exchange Commission, granting unto said attorneys and agents, and each or any
of them, full power and authority to do and perform each and every act and
thing requisite and necessary to be done, as fully to all intents and purposes
as he or she might or could do in person, hereby ratifying and confirming all
that said attorneys and agents, and each of them, or his substitute or
substitutes, may lawfully do or cause to be done by virtue hereof.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pursuant to the requirements of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as
amended, this report has been signed by the following persons on behalf of the
registrant and in the capacities indicated on March&nbsp;31, 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>CERTIFICATIONS</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">I, W. Douglas Parker, certify that:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I have reviewed this annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K of America West
Holdings Corporation;
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Based on my knowledge, this annual report does not contain any untrue
statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make
the statements made, in light of the circumstances under which such statements
were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this annual
report;
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Based on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial
information included in this annual report, fairly present in all material
respects the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of the
registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this annual report;
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The registrant&#146;s other certifying officers and I are responsible for
establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in
Exchange Act Rules&nbsp;13a-14 and 15d-14) for the registrant and have:
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;designed such disclosure controls and procedures to ensure that
material information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated
subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly
during the period in which this annual report is being prepared;
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;evaluated the effectiveness of the registrant&#146;s disclosure controls
and procedures as of a date within 90&nbsp;days prior to the filing date of this
annual report (the &#147;Evaluation Date&#148;); and
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;presented in this annual report our conclusions about the
effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures based on our evaluation
as of the Evaluation Date;
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The registrant&#146;s other certifying officers and I have disclosed, based
on our most recent evaluation, to the registrant&#146;s auditors and the audit
committee of registrant&#146;s board of directors (or persons performing the
equivalent functions):
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;all significant deficiencies in the design or operation of internal
controls which could adversely affect the registrant&#146;s ability to record,
process, summarize and report financial data and have identified for the
registrant&#146;s auditors any material weaknesses in internal controls; and
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other
employees who have a significant role in the registrant&#146;s internal controls;
and
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The registrant&#146;s other certifying officers and I have indicated in this
annual report whether there were significant changes in internal controls or
in other factors that could significantly affect internal controls subsequent
to the date of our most recent evaluation, including any corrective actions
with regard to significant deficiencies and material weaknesses.
</FONT>

<CENTER>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>POWER OF ATTORNEY</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We, the undersigned, directors and officers of America West Airlines,
Inc., do hereby severally constitute and appoint W. Douglas Parker and Linda M.
Mitchell and each or any of them, our true and lawful attorneys and agents,
with full power of substitution and resubstitution, for him or her and in his
or her name, place and stead, in any and all capacities, to sign any and all
amendments to the Registrant&#146;s Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K for the fiscal year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, and to file the same with all exhibits thereto, and
all other documents in connection therewith, with the Securities and Exchange
Commission, granting unto said attorneys and agents, and each or any of them,
full power and authority to do and perform each and every act and thing
requisite and necessary to be done, as fully to all intents and purposes as he
or she might or could do in person, hereby ratifying and confirming all that
said attorneys and agents, and each of them, or his substitute or substitutes,
may lawfully do or cause to be done by virtue hereof.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pursuant to the requirements of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as
amended, this report has been signed by the following persons on behalf of the
registrant and in the capacities indicated on March&nbsp;31, 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>CERTIFICATIONS</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">I, W. Douglas Parker, certify that:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;I have reviewed this annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K of America West
Airlines, Inc.;
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based on my knowledge, this annual report does not contain any untrue
statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make
the statements made, in light of the circumstances under which such statements
were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this annual
report;
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial
information included in this annual report, fairly present in all material
respects the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of the
registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this annual report;
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The registrant&#146;s other certifying officers and I are responsible for
establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in
Exchange Act Rules&nbsp;13a-14 and 15d-14) for the registrant and have:
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp; designed such disclosure controls and procedures to ensure that
material information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated
subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly
during the period in which this annual report is being prepared;
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp; evaluated the effectiveness of the registrant&#146;s disclosure controls
and procedures as of a date within 90&nbsp;days prior to the filing date of this
annual report (the &#147;Evaluation Date&#148;); and
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp; presented in this annual report our conclusions about the
effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures based on our evaluation
as of the Evaluation Date;
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The registrant&#146;s other certifying officers and I have disclosed, based
on our most recent evaluation, to the registrant&#146;s auditors and the audit
committee of registrant&#146;s board of directors (or persons performing the
equivalent functions):
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(a)&nbsp; all significant deficiencies in the design or operation of internal
controls which could adversely affect the registrant&#146;s ability to record,
process, summarize and report financial data and have identified for the
registrant&#146;s auditors any material weaknesses in internal controls; and
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(b)&nbsp; any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other
employees who have a significant role in the registrant&#146;s internal controls;
and
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The registrant&#146;s other certifying officers and I have indicated in this
annual report whether there were significant changes in internal controls or
in other factors that could significantly affect internal controls subsequent
to the date of our most recent evaluation, including any corrective actions
with regard to significant deficiencies and material weaknesses.
</FONT>
<CENTER>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Report of Independent Accountants on<BR>
Financial Statement Schedule</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>To the Board of Directors<BR>
of America West Holdings Corporation:</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our audits of the consolidated financial statements of America West
Holdings Corporation referred to in our report dated March&nbsp;24, 2003 (except
for Notes 2 and 21 as to which the dates are March&nbsp;24, 2003 and February&nbsp;28,
2003, respectively) appearing in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K also included
an audit of the 2002 and 2001 financial statement schedule information included
in the financial statement schedule listed in Item&nbsp;15(a)(2) of this Form&nbsp;10-K.
In our opinion, the 2002 and 2001 financial statement schedule information
presents fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein
when read in conjunction with the related consolidated financial statements for
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001.
</FONT>
<P><FONT size="2">As discussed in the note to the financial statement
schedule, the Company has restated the information for the valuation
allowance on net deferred tax assets for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001.
</font>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP<BR>
Phoenix, Arizona<BR>
March&nbsp;24, 2003
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>The Board of Directors and Stockholders<BR>
America West Holdings Corporation:</B>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">The audit referred to in our report dated March&nbsp;28, 2001, included the related
consolidated financial statement schedule as listed in Item&nbsp;15(a)(2) for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000, included herein. The consolidated financial
statement schedule is the responsibility of the Company&#146;s management. Our
responsibility is to express an opinion on the consolidated financial statement
schedule based on our audit. In our opinion, such consolidated financial
statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic consolidated
financial statements taken as a whole, presents fairly, in all material
respects, the information set forth therein.

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<p><font size="2">The information for the valuation allowance on net
deferred tax assets has been restated for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001 to reflect the tax impact of a restatement
relating to impairment charges. See Note&nbsp;2 of Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements.
</font>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>Report of Independent Accountants on<BR>
Financial Statement Schedule</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>To the Board of Directors<BR>
of America West Airlines, Inc.:</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Our audits of the financial statements of America West Airlines, Inc. referred
to in our report dated March&nbsp;24, 2003 (except for Notes 2 and 20, as to which
the dates are March&nbsp;24, 2003 and February&nbsp;28, 2003, respectively) appearing in
this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K also included an audit of the 2002 and 2001
financial statement schedule information included in the financial statement
schedule listed in Item&nbsp;15(a)(2) of this Form&nbsp;10-K. In our opinion, the 2002
and 2001 financial statement schedule information presents fairly, in all
material respects, the information set forth therein when read in conjunction
with the related financial statements for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and
2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">As discussed in the note to the
financial statement schedule, the Company has restated the
information for the valuation allowance on net deferred tax
assets for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP<BR>
Phoenix, Arizona<BR>
March&nbsp;24, 2003
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">114</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>INDEPENDENT AUDITORS&#146; REPORT ON SCHEDULE</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>The Board of Directors and Stockholder<BR>
America West Airlines, Inc.:</B>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The audit referred to in our report dated March&nbsp;28, 2001, included the
related financial statement schedule as listed in Item&nbsp;15(a)(2) for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2000, included herein. The financial statement schedule is
the responsibility of the Company&#146;s management. Our responsibility is to
express an opinion on the financial statement schedule based on our audit. In
our opinion, such financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to
the basic financial statements taken as a whole, presents fairly, in all
material respects, the information set forth therein.
</FONT>
<P align="left"><FONT size="2">KPMG LLP<BR>
